Posted: June 26, 2014
												Review excerpted from http://www.gamesxtreme.com/article/4118/always-sometimes-monsters-review/ and used with permission. Please note full review contains spoilers.The thing about games with stories is that no matter how your play affects them, someone had to write every bit of it. The choices a game offers-- and their consequences-- say as much about it as the actual gameplay. However, using gameplay to present that story, to create atmosphere, and to immerse you in the scenario is critical to gaming as a narrative medium. Good writing can compensate for lackluster mechanics, while good gameplay can smooth over poor or nonsensical plotlines.For example, Spec Ops: The Line's mediocre gameplay helped lower the player's guard, lulling them into going with the flow during the early stages of the plot. Better mechanics would have made a better game, certainly; but its creators used what they had to enhance the story's power. Another is Papers, Please-- a monotony simulator. It's the most immersive game I've ever played. It pulls you into a rhythm, and the story, told in short, sharp shocks, is punctuation that draws you deeper. Whenever I play the game, my internal monologue is in a strange Boris Badenov accent for days after. Always Sometimes Monsters fails on virtually every level it attempts to engage on.It is made in the wrong engineHonestly, I don't have a problem with RPGMaker being used for commercial products in principle. But it's a hobbyist engine, and Vagabond Dog makes no interesting use of it. The times when it is used (such as for the abortive hunger system, or poorly-constructed minigames), it's bland enough to not even be worth comment. The style of story could have been better served by something like Ren'py, if they'd been willing to go full visual novel for this; after all, they have a few drawn scenes that are reasonably attractive. Twine would probably have been the ideal medium, however, as Vagabond Dog fancies itself as having a strong writing staff (spoilers: they don't), and the story could have been more effective in text alone.The visuals are bad. So, so badThe tile graphics are bland and amateurish, offering essentially no atmosphere (with the notable exception of a single room). It's strange, because at times there is visible effort-- for example, one late-game location is supposed to evoke a dying roadside town, but the repetitive tiles and lack of interesting set pieces make it more forgettable than it should be.The spritework is downright abysmal. As a general rule, they do not emote; with some isolated exceptions, it's possible to play the entire game and see only a gratuitous aiming-a-gun motion. Instead, when the script calls for a visual reaction, tiny emote bubbles pop up over characters' heads-- like a heart, or a music note, or anime-style sweat drops and vein-pops. This, frankly, has never looked good, and it's never wise to evoke visual stylings that were implemented as a cost-cutting measure in low-budget cartoons.One would expect, given the above, that character portraits used for dialogue would do some of the heavy visual lifting-- many story-driven games use them to great effect. These don't. While not aesthetically offensive, they're entirely static. When even the most emotional exchanges are done with the same unchanging monotony as ordering a burger at McDonald's, it's hard to take the whole thing seriously.Apparently there are six credited artists. Six.The sound design is not goodThe music doesn't help the mood. In a vacuum it might be pleasant enough to listen to, but the emotionless (if upbeat) background synth offers nothing to a scene. It also doesn't always loop properly, at times inserting a long, noticeable silence before restarting. Neither does Vagabond Dog seem to know what a music cue is; you'll never hear it used to enhance an emotional scene.Even the tiniest of sound effects would have been a huge improvement. As it is, their inclusion is exceedingly, ridiculously rare. The intrusive emote bubbles, for example, could have seemed a little less disconnected if they had them. Instead, the times that sound effects are used, they're for things like playing fart noises when you interact with a toilet.Male or female, straight or gay, black or white?Vagabond Dog really wants us to be talking about this, so let's. I really believe that if you can't do something right, you shouldn't do it at all. Always Sometimes Monsters does it wrong in ways I never imagined they would. But I'm getting ahead of myself; let's start with the good they've done. The game does capably display, at times, just how people will react differently-- consciously or no-- to, say, a person of colour, or a woman, rather than to the by-default straight white man. The first character I selected was a straight (ASM gives no attention to bisexual people) white woman, and in short order, a male character was making blatant passes at me that I'm sure another male wouldn't have gotten. While the scene swiftly lost any pretense of subtlety, it still wasn't that bad.Unfortunately, the longer the game drags on, the less likely it is that your starting choice matters. When it does matter, it's mostly just for the sorts of insults other characters direct at you. Ultimately, no matter what identity you selected, you are always the same character in the story. Your dialogue is the same, and the plot is the same. Your black trans lesbian has lived the same life, and reacts to plot events in the exact same way, as your cis white heterosexual man. This is madness.

Posted: December 22, 2014
												I like RPGs, and I find that the closer to real life it is --no magic, supernatural ghosties or demons or 'anime logic' plaguing it-- the more invested I am in it.Yadda yadda yadda, it was a fun game. You have no tutorial from the very start. If you've played a game of this type before, you can *assume* (and be correct) in that you move with arrow keys/WASD and confirm/prompt with Space/Enter, mouse not required. That's good!What I found confusing was the very first scene, which was essentially your sprite lobby in the form of a party. You choose which person to take a swig of alcohol with (being the unofficial straight edge person that I am it didn't feel right, but whatever, I'm still a child in an adult woman's body so I should suck it up to keep the game moving xP), and then choosing among the throng on the patio who your "lover" is. I didn't know this was how my avatar was chosen so I picked a cute-looking guy in a brown hoodie and once I realized I was picking my partner's avatar I just walked up to a nice intellectual with a blue sweater. Together, we were ALEX and MISCHA. And our love, for the long game time it was--and the fairly brief real time minutes it was--was beautiful. But I had to go and ♥♥♥♥ it up and now I'm pining for my babe as a deadbeat writer in a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ apartment.And that's where I start! In a rundown, bum-filled city with a day to procure $500 to pay rent because apparently I'm that irresponsible and that's only the first 10 minutes of the game! Freaking Adventure Quest up in this ♥♥♥♥♥!The little observations my character makes are a mixture of deadpan snark and actual emotion. When you pick a choice between being a complete ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ or actual decent human being or at times neutral, the dialogue corresponds with it. I find that in some RPGs your character is secretly aligned with a temperament already and if your choices go against that temperament that you have built up or is already in place, your choice is played out halfheartedly, which is lame. So what if I want to change my character's outlook half way through?! The puppy needs a home! I don't care if I robbed that game's safe of their start-up money two minutes prior, I'm a changed man/lady/sprite-thing!This game is a slice of life, find-your-own-way, make-ends-meet, there-are-quite-a-few-ways-you-can-go-about-this, but-don't-♥♥♥♥-it-up-too-hard-ya? RPG that I settled into almost immediately. The problem with ME, not the game, is that I'm so indecisive. I'm that person who has at least three fingers on different pages when reading Choose Your Own Adventure books (one joke from Family Guy comes to mind "AAah! a dragon! Lois my finger was on the page! Do you see it Lois?! Do you see!") so making big 'this or that' decisions in this game was nail-biting and I glanced at one of Steam's "Perfect Ending" guides just to see if I was heading in a relatively good direction on my own (I was, hurray for me!).I don't know about you, but games like these...I play as if this were real life because as delayed as I am in understanding social skills, I still recognize and understand that there is right and wrong to be followed. I played my character as close to my own personal tenants as possible and reeled in urges to steal as much as possible (I just love snapping up free things. It's a curse and a blessing) but I think what makes this game worthwhile is realizing that my decisions are--morally at least--the right ones and I'm a bit proud of myself for guiding my imaginary self through this gray concrete jungle to something hopefully better, filled with understanding, connections with old faces and new ones, and trying to set things right.And I recommend this game if you want to feel like I do. Realistic situations (at least from my limited perspective, ha), engaging characters that you actually care to read what they say (not entirely memorable, but I recall who they are when I see them appear time and again on my journey to that big sunset stretching across the highway or whatever I'm aiming for), and a little leeway for you to do a bit of what you want on the side while still keeping in mind that you're on a schedule as soon as you sign yourself up for some commitments and odd jobs. It really is like real life. Sort of. A fraction of real life.Oh, quick critique!I found that I was pressing the equivalent of the fast-forward button for text because I hate waiting for it to be spelled out and instead like it to be just all there for me to read at once and then continue; when I did I often pressed a choice that I didn't know was going to appear and made a few mistakes. Quite frustrating because I'm used to fast-forwarding, then after pressing "continue" the prompt comes up then. Just now I told a guy to ♥♥♥♥ himself. Why must the rudest choices be highlighted first!? Grrrr

Posted: August 13, 2014
												This game is easily one of the best games I've ever played. It shot right into my top ten after my second playthrough. Dead serious.This game is just brilliant. The dialog is beautiful and grounded, and the situations you find yourself in are both harsh and powerful. A few minor bits, like being bribed during a journalism job, don't match up, but how you handle those situations can still bring completely unexpected outcomes.But the real brilliant thing here is how choice is handled. This isn't like a visual novel; there's one set path the game has, and two endings that can result. However, everything else depends on what you do, and there is an incredible amount of weight to each choice you make. I don't mean your own monotary gain; that can be a factor, but not the main factor. The real factor is if you can live with yourself after what you do; do you take the harder route and try to do the right thing, or do you take a shortcut or endulge in something? Will that affect a character you've grown attached to? How will selfish or selfless actions affect others? Does the "right" choice always have the positive outcome?This is a game where choices can be minor and insignifficant, like many in real life, or life changing for either you or the person lucky or unlucky enough to come across you. My first playthrough as as the nicest guy imaginable, and it lead me to doing something surprisingly despicable. However, as I played as a harsher character, situations I handled with peaceful outcomes before suddenly turned in a way I never expected and left a clump in my throat.The line between good and evil is paper thin, and this game brilliantly gets that, all while showing beauty and complexity in nearly every character. This game really deserves two playthroughs so you can see sides to characters you never saw before. The writing is amazing, the characters are all memorable, even the most minor, and the limited mechanics and graphics can all be forgiven by just how much is gotten right here.Only complaint; Memes and references seep in at a few points. They don't ruin the game, but it dates it a tad. Other than that, play this game.

Posted: August 21, 2014
												If given four words to describe the contents of Always Sometimes Monsters, they would all happen to begin with the letter 'C':  Coincidence, circumstance, choice, and consequence.  Unfortunately, if I were to give a letter grade to the overall game and my experience, I would have to be quite forgiving to remain using the letter 'C'.A "life simulator" if you will, this is a game that plants you into a world where your hopes and dreams haven't proceeded as planned.  In a time where it has become a struggle to earn enough money to pay for food or keep a roof over your head, you find yourself invited to a wedding in a distant city.  You are tasked to find your way there within a month's time, and along the road many scenarios and options are presented to tailor your experience in exactly how you will (or will not) achieve your goal.The freedom of choice is apparent upon starting the game and persists throughout to an extent.  Sacrifice to help a friend or be selfish?  Take sides with party X or organization Y?  Take the high road or the low?  Many situations might give you pause to stop and consider your choices before committing.  Do you want to retain moral character or will the means justify the ends?  All of it is left to you as the player and will ultimately decide your fate.In the end, however, I was left rather unsatistfied with the game as a whole.  I felt as though my personal choices led to the same general path I might have ended up at had I gone the opposite direction.  Sure, one or two characters would have had different opinions of who I was in the end, maybe they'd be there in the final scene or maybe not.  But what impact did I have on the world?  ...Very little, it seems.  I chose to go with more of an upstanding citizen and aide (though not in EVERY scenario, hence the appropriate title), and as a result the choices seemed rote.  As a game that asks you to make difficult decisions, there was never a moment where I felt like I NEEDED to break out of the role I had chosen.  It felt no different to a Mass Effect game: if you play a paragon character, you make paragon choices in just about every situation.  Therefore, for a game all about choices and consequences, Always Sometimes Monsters rarely presented anything that felt meaningful.  As for the "game" part of the game, it's pretty messy and rarely flows well.  Conversations are held up and constantly prolonged with bubbles floating above characters' heads displaying elipses or hearts or exclamation points, none of which can be hurried with button presses or disabled in the options.  Just as disrupting is a big clock that pops up and remains on screen for at least a full five seconds whenever each "stage" of the day transitions from one to the next.And the mini-games.  OH, the mini-games.  Some exist to reward you in the form of money or key items.  Some are there just to spice up the world and give you something else to do off the beaten path.  However, ALL of them are rather monotonous, if not downright frustrating from time to time.  Need to puzzle out a mini-game over five or ten minutes for some cash once, that's okay.  Need to repeat that same puzzle a dozen times with hardly any variables changing, each lasting the same five to ten minutes?  It's boring and tedious.  I spent twelve hours in the game, and I would have been much more satisfied with the experience if it were cut in half.  ...At a bare minimum.  And when a mini-game causes you to savescum a few dozen times, there's something wrong.  This is a piece of work that asks you to consider your choices and their consequences, so its aim has gone awry when you're in a postion where you find yourself quitting and reloading to go back to previous saves.Due to the nature of how this game plays with its choices, I know that I missed a lot of content by making the decisions I did.  There's a lot left to see and experience.  Normally I'd be gung ho to get right back into it to see everything I could.  ...But not with Always Sometimes Monsters.  I didn't finish it excitedly to see what ending might unfold; I finished it over a few play sessions, each start more and more begrudgingly, only to get it done and out of the way.  I was not invested in my character or the world or the emotions it tried (and failed) to stir within me.  I was only pushing buttons to see what the game had to offer, and in the end I wasn't all that interested, surprised, or all that enthralled.  For a "cerebral" game that wanted me to think or care, it failed with me.   It doesn't stand up to similar "head space" games.  Gone Home made me curious and sympathetic.  To The Moon gave me wonder, tugged at my heart, and literally brought me to tears of joy and sadness simultaneously.  ...Always Sometimes Monsters far too often made me slump in my chair, toss back my head and roll my eyes, and caused me to breathe out grunts of annoyance and exasperation. Thus, I can't recommend it.  Sorry, Vagabond Dogs.  I wanted to like it.  It just didn't do it for me.

												Amazing game!It's a very dramatic and emotional kind of game. The money I spent on getting this game was worth every dollar.Almost Sometimes Monsters revolves around  you , or your character. You are faced with many choices that are obvious and hidden. It's like playing a game made by Telltale Games mixed with Rockstar games. 												My overall opinion: A pretty good game, it won't be liked by some people but I gotta say the story and the choices you make/say really did feel like a real choice and the ending wasn't set in stone and there are quite a few ways your journey may end earlier or differently(WARNING! THERE ARE SOME HINTED SPOILERS!)(This Is Just My Own Personal Opinion And How I Felt The Game Was To Me And You Might Feel Different To My Point Of View So Please Be Nice Kay? =)It wasn't a game where you can just get the best ending by just rushing to the end and picking the right dialog, it was focused on choices and life decisions that can cause your own story to end suddenly by taking the wrong turn in life. There are some flaws that I felt made the game feel annoying at some points like the boxing minigame or earning enough income in a short time open up another dialog option later in the story but without knowing all this beforehand you'll be left with just one thing, your own personal choice. (and this is without being a cheat and reading a how-to guide!)The epilogue felt open ended and you cannot revisit the previous town/cities to check up on how they are all doing and your main love interest (if you choose to persue it) simply locks him/herself in a room and you end up having a limit set of options you could do.I truely wished there was abit more to the story in the epilogue, I kinda felt cheated after going through everything just to have my main love interest lock him/herself in so I cannot see or talk to him/her and having it end just like that because I felt there could be abit more story between the main character and the love interest rather than relying mostly on flashback/dreams and maybe having them go together to revisit the town/cities the main character have gone to and see where it goes from there.Heres hoping for dlc or a sequel! but I doubt they'd do that, happens too often~ =P Anyways, this is a good game in which I will play again to see what else it has to offer and the main theme of the game is probably the choice in life and maybe something else =P , I hope you enjoy it if you do buy the game, its total recommended game to get!

Posted: December 23, 2014
												Probably one of the best games I've ever played. I enjoyed every bit of the game, truly, but here are the key parts.The first thing that I instantly noticed was how well the introduction was created. The first scene was a little bit bewildering and confusing since I had no idea what was happening. The first scene took only like three minutes, and that's when the magic began. The way the character and the lover were chosen and introduced was clever. Whereas most games have the character creation not really tied to the story or it's just there at the beginning related to nothing *looks at the Elder Scrolls IV* the character creation really made you feel like a part of the story right off the bat. One of my favourite bits was that you can choose anyone to be your character and you can choose anyone to be the significant others, and whom you choose doesn't have a whole bunch of effects. Sure, there might be a few gay innuendos from the friendly neighbour or some racist butt faces being racist against you and your *black friend (his boss)*, but there isn't anyone saying it's wrong.Because that's not what this game is about.As the developers have stated, the game doesn't care. It doesn't care if you decide to sell the dog to be a police dog, a fight pit dog, or return it back to the owner. The charm about this game is that it's not up to the game to make you content with what you do. There isn't anybody patting you on the back for doing the right thing (something that doesn't exist in this game, as you'll see) or someone telling you that you're a screw up if you do the evil thing (also doesn't really exist), it's practically only you who will be the judge of you. If you feel like you did the wrong thing, then you did the wrong thing. The game doesn't care, and it most likely won't impact you. If you feel like you did the right thing, then you did the right thing. Again, the game doesn't care.What really makes this game great is what I said before: it's special to you because you make it special. It's just you doing the things in the game, with very little forced upon you. You can take that screwdriver and pawn it off simply because you're short on cash. Whoever owned the screwdriver might be mad, but you don't see it, it doesn't effect you negatively. You benefit, he loses. Or you might decide to not accept the bribe. You lose some, others gain some. It's take or pull, but it's what you make of it. Have fun.

Posted: June 24, 2015
												Always Sometimes Monsters is an intriguing game where your decisions impact the narrative. While not an entirely new concept, this game manages to keep things interesting most of the time. Gameplay The gameplay in Always Sometimes Monsters is primarily about making choices. In the beginning of the game, you choose your character by deciding who to toast with at a party, and then choose your love interest by going to the balcony and talking with one of the many characters. It makes character selection more interesting than just picking from a menu. Also, you are able to choose from a diverse group of male/female characters and can choose to be either heterosexual or homosexual.There is an in-game clock of sorts that breaks the day up into 3 parts - morning, afternoon, and night. You can do one job/event per time of day, and some tasks require a certain time of day. After completing the task, that part of the day is automatically over. This is where making choices comes into play. You have to decide what you are going to do for each segment of the day, and the choices you make during those jobs and events affect the way the story unfolds. You have 30 in-game days to reach a particular destination (I won't spoil what that is, since it is a major part of the story).There are some mini-games as well, but to be honest, they were not too interesting to me. I tried each one once or twice, but I did not have the desire to revisit them. Lastly, there are optional figures to collect that feature characters from various indie games, though I'm not sure if they serve a purpose other than to be collected for fun (they can be sold to the pawn shop for a little extra money, but I preferred to keep them in my collection). Story I won't spoil anything, but the actual game starts one year after the party I mentioned previously where you select your character. You are basically trying to get your life back on track. There are several main areas in the game, and each has its own story and set of quests you will need to do in order to make it to the next area. This is unfortunately where the game is hit-or-miss, since it is a story-driven game. Some characters and events are intriguing, while others just simply are not (at least in my opinion). However, keep in mind that I only played through the game once, so my choices may not have led to all of the most interesting events.Dialogue is good about 70% of the time, but the rest of it is not quite at the same level of quality. It feels like certain parts are trying to be very mature, but they don't always quite hit the mark. It's not terrible by any means, but just something I wanted to point out. There are also some spelling and grammar mistakes that I encountered on more than a few occasions. It's not a deal-breaker, but those kinds of mistakes sometimes took me out of the moment. I understand that this is an indie game and it's not easy to find every little mistake during the development process, though. Sound The songs are pretty cool for the most part - simple yet catchy electronic music. Be aware that there are some songs that got annoying after a while, but only if I was in a particular area for an extended period of time. If you really love that type of music, you may not find it to be too annoying. I just felt like there was a lack of variety. The sound effects were fine and I have no complaints about them. Conclusion Despite its flaws, I do recommend this game. It was made using RPG Maker, and as someone who has used those tools before, I must say that it is impressive what these developers were able to do with it. If you enjoy story-driven games where your choices matter, then Always Sometimes Monsters is worth your time.

Posted: December 31, 2015
												I want to give this a thumbs down because of how much of an emotional wreck I am right now, but I don't really want to not recommend a game just because of the negative emotion it gave me. For those who have finished this game would understand me, that is, if everything ended sucky for them as well.**MIGHT spoil the game, but I am trying to avoid any spoilers**This game was pretty great, I'm just quite an emotional person and feels always get to me right away. I mean, this game makes me think, we don't easily forget the people that make life worth living, do we?I mean, my character in this game has done so much and in the end, he just gets thrown around like an animal and gets his heart completely crushed. Too much effort, just for that to happen... Does a legacy of effort mean anything in this world anymore?If I had a happy ending, that would be Sam standing there and I would be the cause of HIS/HER unhappy ending. Maybe Sam's been as miserable as me. Maybe he/she doesn't deserve an unhappy ending...but it's either me or the other person who gets that happiness; there always has to be one person who has to be the miserable one. Should I accept my fate and stay silent?No matter what choice we make in this world...there are always sometimes monsters.__Okay, so enough of that crap. There were some things in this game that I could definitely see me doing / see happen to me in the future so I got really into it. I thought this game was totally worth it ESPECIALLY if it's on sale. There's romance, a lot of comedy, oh, and a hecka lot of quotes I wish I wrote down (I may or may not have used some above). I'd definitely recommend this to people who like romance and comedy - and people who like feels.I would write a PROS list, but my opinion about what I like doesn't really matter. Different people like different things. BUT I am going to write a CON list because sometimes we gotta look at the bad before caring too much about the good.Cons:-Sometimes the objectives in this game isn't as specific as the others (might get lost/confused about what you're supposed to do next) but you'll get back in track after a few minutes of wandering.-There were times where this game was boring *cough* Tofu job *cough* but it added to the steadiness of the game (rather than having too much stuff like maybe uh uhm yeah the ending bye)-Choices that leave you thinking after a while-If you're SUPER emotional and a sissy like me, you'd be feeling uncomfortable and broken-CHARACTERS THAT MAKE YOU WANT TO BREAK THINGS-Sam -why does the kid only want to fish for crabs?? are people going to notice the floating corpse?? and HOW ABOUT THAT SMASHED WINDOW?!-i need money and food-some of the music made my eyes twitch (sorry)-Most of the guys did not look attractive. Only the females looked nice (most of the time)Pros:(I said I wouldn't, but I want to write just a FEW things)-The game is steady, not too much going on.-Dream scenes - oh my god I love it when games have these-The game lasted longer than I thought it would (I would always be anxious to play but I was too scared to finish it)[there are a lot more probs, I am just too upset to focus on the good things right now]__Well, I hope you guys enjoy this game, if you do buy it. Maybe gift your friend the game as well and then compare choices. And I hope someone would list all the quotes in this game and put them on wiki/imdb or some website or something. All the quotes in this game are magnificent. The deep quotes always get to me oh my god. Anyways, enjoyt the game. And thanks to the people who read through all my nonsense.

												I'm currently burning through my Steam library playing the games I've never installed. So this review will be pretty brief and based on the hour and a half I've played.I think I got this game in a bundle at some point. I installed it today not knowing what to expect since I hadn't yet looked into what this game was past the name. What i got was what I can only describe as a Super NES melodrama. Not that its a bad thing, mind you. Sometimes always monsters is very unique. Without going into spoilers, this plays like an old adventure game. You'll walk around talking to people and interacting with the environment. The graphic style looks like something from the 16 bit era. The music is pretty cool too. This is mostly a semi interactive visual novel, though. I don't believe the branching paths branch all that far in that from what I've played so far, It seems that the main character is locked into either doing certain things or losing the game altogether. Maybe I'm wrong. All in all though, Always Sometimes Monsters is pretty good and worth checking out. The 10 dollar price tag does seem a wee bit high so grab it on sale if you can.

Posted: May 6, 2015
												Spoilers Included:Majors in a story-telling aspect with allusion to some of your choices actually mattering with some interesting social commentary. Loses it’s steam due to tedious repetitive segments complete with poor pacing, obvious plot twists, and revolving around mostly nothing but your grinding/luck with money.What’s interesting is it actually gives away it’s concept pretty early while talking to the meta in-game developers as “Would you be interested in playing a game where you’re not the hero” and the game tries to accomplish just that. You stem into this journey in attempt to see your partner betrothed at someone else’s hand and the cost of doing such may cost you your own morality and people will question that as time passes but in the end it just comes to this giant “meh” of a selective ending unless you really want♥♥♥♥♥♥to warp into the soap opera zone.The characters 8/10 of the times are cynical ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s, their attempt to get you connected to your partner completely revolves around these short flashbacks you get every maybe 30% of game completion with very little substance whatsoever and devalues the plot by about 50%, it’s an attempt to give you a visual novel experience by Devolver Digital standards (surprise, surprise) and just barely manages to withhold it’s own without coming off as pointless.

												Surprisingly, I've learned a lot about myself from this charming 8-bit game. This game gives you many, many choices that often change the outcome of a situation, chapter, or even the entire game. Some are black and white moral choices, others are very gray. What would you do for love? What would you do for your friend? What would you do for a paycheck? What would you do for...bacon?!Things That Happened In Game:*Victim of racism in first ten minutes of gameplay. *Homeless.*Starved to death, start over, sustain self on bacon.*Stole a man's job, then saved him from killing himself.*Worked temp job making soy burgers for hippies, enjoyed more than real life job.*Experienced sexism as I was hit on by jerk foreman. Put up with it for a paycheck.*Died in my sleep, start over, remember to eat before bed! *Chose to make tofu over killing piglets, even though it paid less. Ironically, I sustain myself on bacon. *Broke into mansion, hacked computer, stole sex scandal pics, blackmailed surgeon to save best friend's girlfriend.*Scalp Massage. Oh, yeah. *Tricked drug addict into losing money which I then pocket.*Got top score in a video game.*Stole the start up money for this game while in game and broke the fourth wall, sending me back in time, making me a Time Lord. Start over. Eat more bacon.*Rigged an election. Oh, don't look at me like that. They were both bad choices, anyway.

Posted: May 10, 2015
												5/10.This is a heavily story-focused game.  No combat...which is okay!You follow a selected protagonist through a series of difficult life choices.  The way Vagabond Dog wrote the story, you really feel invested in the characters and the choices you're making.  That's definitely a positive.  However, as far as the main story goes, I feel that many of your choices don't have too much of an efffect, and sometimes I felt too railroaded.  I don't intend to spoil any story-points, but I felt a little cheated by the ending.Beyond choice-making, the game has a few minigames to play in order to earn cash.  99 percent of them felt like grinding in an old RPG without any of the fun of a battle system.  As I stated before, no battle system is okay.  However, I would expect the minigames to be somewhat entertaining if they're going to be replacing it completely.Overall, this game is worth checking out if you enjoy throw-back pixel-graphic games and an interesting story that makes you think.  This game definitely is a standout for being different and interesting.  The entertainment quality simply suffered in a few places.

Posted: January 25, 2016
												Did I enjoy it: YesIs it a good game: Debateable, but I'm going to say yesCons can basically all be pointed back to the choice of RPG Maker as the engine. However, if you can look past that you'll find a game that tackles some interesting topics in a novel way.How many games allow you the opportuntiy to be homeless and unemployed? Or face discrimination based on your race, sex or sexuality? Even the minigames in which you make money are an exercise in dealing with boredom - probably an artistic choice on the designer's part, but not a smart mvoe when making a game.All in all, I found it engrossing. It's basically a road-trip movie that takes itself seriously, and wants to explroe the darker side of the modern world. Dialogue can get incredibly preachy and go on too long about simple philosophical concepts, and some people feel they were rail-roaded too much in the latetr part of the game after the initial 'open world' experience of the first act, but these are minor niggles. The fact that most NPCs treat you differently based on race, sex and age are all commendable, showing that these choices matter.Always Sometimes Monsters delivers a good story, has some solid points to make and dares to do something different.

												I really loved this game, though the possible endings were kind of disappointing. It was mostly a game about the journey, though.I especially loved the subtle way it dealt with issues like sexism, racism, homophobia, etc. through dialogue that was intentionally inserted to make you cringe. And did anyone else see the sly Monsanto reference in the seed-planting job?Oh, and the soundtrack was AWESOME. <3I'll definitely be replaying this.

Posted: June 24, 2015
												Always Sometimes Monsters is an intriguing game where your decisions impact the narrative. While not an entirely new concept, this game manages to keep things interesting most of the time. Gameplay The gameplay in Always Sometimes Monsters is primarily about making choices. In the beginning of the game, you choose your character by deciding who to toast with at a party, and then choose your love interest by going to the balcony and talking with one of the many characters. It makes character selection more interesting than just picking from a menu. Also, you are able to choose from a diverse group of male/female characters and can choose to be either heterosexual or homosexual.There is an in-game clock of sorts that breaks the day up into 3 parts - morning, afternoon, and night. You can do one job/event per time of day, and some tasks require a certain time of day. After completing the task, that part of the day is automatically over. This is where making choices comes into play. You have to decide what you are going to do for each segment of the day, and the choices you make during those jobs and events affect the way the story unfolds. You have 30 in-game days to reach a particular destination (I won't spoil what that is, since it is a major part of the story).There are some mini-games as well, but to be honest, they were not too interesting to me. I tried each one once or twice, but I did not have the desire to revisit them. Lastly, there are optional figures to collect that feature characters from various indie games, though I'm not sure if they serve a purpose other than to be collected for fun (they can be sold to the pawn shop for a little extra money, but I preferred to keep them in my collection). Story I won't spoil anything, but the actual game starts one year after the party I mentioned previously where you select your character. You are basically trying to get your life back on track. There are several main areas in the game, and each has its own story and set of quests you will need to do in order to make it to the next area. This is unfortunately where the game is hit-or-miss, since it is a story-driven game. Some characters and events are intriguing, while others just simply are not (at least in my opinion). However, keep in mind that I only played through the game once, so my choices may not have led to all of the most interesting events.Dialogue is good about 70% of the time, but the rest of it is not quite at the same level of quality. It feels like certain parts are trying to be very mature, but they don't always quite hit the mark. It's not terrible by any means, but just something I wanted to point out. There are also some spelling and grammar mistakes that I encountered on more than a few occasions. It's not a deal-breaker, but those kinds of mistakes sometimes took me out of the moment. I understand that this is an indie game and it's not easy to find every little mistake during the development process, though. Sound The songs are pretty cool for the most part - simple yet catchy electronic music. Be aware that there are some songs that got annoying after a while, but only if I was in a particular area for an extended period of time. If you really love that type of music, you may not find it to be too annoying. I just felt like there was a lack of variety. The sound effects were fine and I have no complaints about them. Conclusion Despite its flaws, I do recommend this game. It was made using RPG Maker, and as someone who has used those tools before, I must say that it is impressive what these developers were able to do with it. If you enjoy story-driven games where your choices matter, then Always Sometimes Monsters is worth your time.

Posted: May 6, 2015
												There is a difference between a sad story and a depressing story.After a sad story we feel catharsis. We feel like we've explored an idea, like we've walked in another person's shoes. Sure, the story didn't turn out well, but not everything in life does. We can learn from it. Sad stories serve a purpose.A depressing story, on the other hand, tells us nothing we don't already know. Life sucks. Work is boring and unfulfilling. Society is cruel and unfair. Damn near nobody cares about us; they're all out to get their own. Connections we make in our lives are all the more precious for being freaking rare, and we have to treasure the few good things we have for the limited time we still have them. We know all that.After experiencing a sad story, you feel cleansed. After experiencing a depressing story, you want 1.4 hours of your life back.Judging by my rating, in which category do you think I place this ridiculous runaround of a game?I guess someone who's had a much easier life than mine might find a game like this eye-opening. Honestly, though, it's so far removed from reality anyway that it can't even be instructive.

Posted: May 29, 2014
												"Humble thyself or ye shall be humbled." "There is none good, no, not one." During my ten hour playthrough I constantly thought of these Biblical teachings so that I would make the best possible "morally right" choices through the game. Then again, morals are only based on popular opinion, and this game really digs deep into our morals. No matter the conclusion, be it a sad, a good, or a controversial ending, the outcomes really weighed upon me, which goes to show that a game doesn't need great graphics to tell a good story. That is what I believe the developers at Vagabond Dog were trying to do: make a story to be remembered for years to come, be it sad, good, or controversial. For ten dollars, Always Sometimes Monsters will take you on a journey of love, sacrifice, hate, and greed. This game invites you to think about your own morals.

Posted: January 2, 2015
												I have nothing nice to say, but I have put near 8 hours into the game and spent money on it, so I am going to vent a little. Always Sometimes Monsters isn't just a let down on my expectations, it's a let down of a game. It fails at the one thing a game should always prioritize on being: Fun. It fails as being fun. It fails at telling an immersive story. It fails at pacing. It fails from a control standpoint. However it doesn't fail on one aspect. It doesn't fail at being a chore. It's so anti-game that it hurts me. I hate being overy critical, but when I invest the time and the climax is a massive disappointment, I can't help but be this way.Is it the fault of the developer? In my opinion, I don't always believe so. Sure, it's easy to blame them cause I mean they did create the game after all, but it was their vision at the end of the day, and they weren't wrong for producing it. However, it is their fault for having a premise, and making it a long grind of futility and boredom. It's so damn boring. I can go into more details in a future edit if people REALLY want me to but every other review has done a good job of dealing with the details. I just wanted to vent over how disappointed I was.

Posted: January 9, 2015
												The one thing this game has going for it is that you can tell it was a labor of love.  It feels very personal, as if the developers created it without the intention of showing it to anyone else, and there's something charming about that.Unfortunately, the awkward writing, the nonsensical plot, and especially the really tedious gameplay (culminating in having to gamble up to a ridiculous amount of money to get the best ending) are too much.  There were several pretty annoying glitches, one where events weren't triggered at the right time and resulted in seeing the same dialogue more than once, and one where a minigame was just completely broken. So I played through almost all of the game until I reached the part I described in the spoiler, and then I just decided it wasn't worth the time and looked up the endings. Perhaps watch a playthrough on Youtube so you can skip the tedious parts.

Posted: June 4, 2014
												Overall I enjoyed this game. The story gave a lot of choice and presented some interesting dilemmas, although some parts did tend to drag on a little bit. I enjoyed the ending, and while I would be a little interested to see how the story can play out with different choices, the game doesn't have a lot of replay value.Not much to say about the graphics - the screenshots basically tell you all you need to know. The art is not amazing, but decent. The music on the other hand was generally great, although some tracks were a bit irritating. The developers crammed in a bunch of references to other indie titles with collectable items, and references game that try to remind you repeatedly that you're playing an indie game right now and I found it a little annoying. There's a fair number of mini games scattered throughout the game as well, though most of them are mediocre, if not downright terrible. Thankfully, the bad ones are completely optional. The core of the game is in the narritive and managing your money. My only complaint there would be that the whole stamina system is not well explained, I was never sure what the consequences of not eating would be and was never told. Overall, Always Sometimes Monsters is a decent game, though there are better games out there. The fact that there is so much choice tends to mean that a lot of the dialogue feels very generic and weakens the narritive. Even still, the price is right, and if you have the time to play it I'd reccomend picking it up. There are certainly better stories out there, but seeing how your version of this one plays out is worth the time.

Posted: May 26, 2014
												I don't usually write reviews, but after finishing this game I felt like I had to.I've played a lot of games with morality systems and choices. While some have done a better job of making me feel the consequences of my actions, most are hit and miss. Always Sometimes Monsters manages to make every choice I make feel like I've made a real decision. And they all have consequences that I did not even think about before while I made them. From who I help to who I don't help, every thing I've done came back to haunt me, for better or for worse. Always sometimes monsters is one of those rare games that lives up to it's claims.I want to write this review without spoilers, which puts me in a bind for discussing the story. Egoraptor did a video once, where he emphasized the difference between telling a player about your game, and showing them how the game works through the actual gameplay. Through your journey, you don't have to be told how hard your character has it. You feel every inch that they struggle. You feel every bit of boredom, tedium and eventually the fear. You become invested in what you're doing and the game very rarely engineers a situation to make you feel bad. Every tragedy, every guilty pang is your fault and the game makes no attempt to pretend that it's not due to your actions. But the same goes for every triumph. Every success, every small victory is all because of you and what you have decided to do. It is the biggest guilt trip, but you honestly feel that warm fuzzy feeling when you do something honestly good.I heard the game described at one point as "To the Moon mixed with Cart Life". Those of you who've played both, as I have, can attest to this fact. It's an emotional rollercoaster full of hard choices and honestly, with no guarantee of success. I suppose this game is somewhat like life, which is the best thing I can think about this game. It's only 9 dollars at release, 10 dollars normally. If you have the money, then give this game a try. Or don't. After all, the choice is always yorus to make.

Posted: June 5, 2014
												Have you ever promised something to someone and didn't follow thru?Did you ever miss out on a concert to spend time with your boyfriend/girlfriend/wife/husband?What were the consequences of your choices? That is what this game is trying to explain that we live far more complex lives than we think and it is changing the way we look at the medium of video games.  Its not about acheviments, high scores or saving the world.  This games makes the player realize that the choices we make have an impact on the people and world around us.  While its not a traditional game it is an experament that video games can be art and delve into the human condition.  If you are going into this game with doubts I'd say play it and it may or may not be for you but for me it made me realize that we can have major impacts on lives by making trivial decsions.  It's def something to think about.

Posted: May 26, 2014
												Always Sometimes Monsters might not be the best RPG-Maker game I've ever played, but it's certainly one of the most unique, as it puts a huge emphasis on choices. That begins with the intro (that seems disonnected to the rest for a long time) where you can decide to listen to the person telling the story or simply shoot him and end it before it gets going.And after that you land at a party that is actually a character selection in disguise. Choose your main character and then the person you will be chasing after for the remainder of the game, which might take 7+ hours, depending on how much you do. I certainly could have done more, since I had about 10 days to spare from the 30 day countdown.With only one playthrough I cannot say how much of the choices are real and how much illusions, but you can certainly get some people killed or simply decide if you want to be a nice person or a real ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s who would even rob indie developers of the little money they have.Therefore I can only recommend it. One of the few commercial rpg-maker games that is worth every cent. It might be a little rough around the edges, but it's nothing that couldn't be fixed with a few updates.

Posted: May 30, 2014
												Always Sometimes Monsters is a little game about choice.At nearly every turn the player is put in a situation in which they must make a decision, and live with the consequences. Though the game wil always guide you through the key points, how and why you get there vary with each playthrough.The game also likes to test your morality. There are many situations in which you must decide who to screw over, or whether you're going to play dirty.The game is fairly short, taking only a few hours to get through, but considering the sheer number of choices (and multiple endings) it has extreme replayability. The game also has a rather unique way to pick ones charcter, and allows for you to play either sex and orientation.While having only presently played through twice, I look forward to trying to hunt down all the hidden details and possible outcomes in hopes of getting that Happy Ending.If I had to give a rating, 'twould be 4.5/5.

Posted: May 3, 2015
												It's an RPG Maker game so you already know it offers the most basic of gameplay in an .exe that hopefully works without having to change some properties. Can't say anything new about that or recommend it to people who are tired with those types of Verge RPG programs from way back. The main draw for this one is its choose-your-own-adventure story system. Unfortunately, that means it had better be written well to be worth $10. Same goes for the $5 soundtrack, which is also too boring and uninspiring to be worth it.Gamers have a very low bar for what’s considered good writing, it seems. No achievement for shooting that first long-winded bum who kept prattling on about choice? C’mon, we were supposed to not hate that dialogue? The biggest problem with moral dilemma stories written by gamers is that it’s so obvious what the intended choice is. They all think the same. Besides, when you have the choice between “Well, I guess you’re right if you really think about it” and “Get the ♥♥♥♥ out of here, I’m not an awful person ugh,” it’s not hard to figure out which path the writer’s hoping you choose, especially since there’s always a trigger involved. Sex? Kinda sketchy. Drugs? Tools of the devil. Old people? Gotta respect ‘em. Do I steal the game dev’s money or do I leave it alone? I wonder which one results in the Game Over.“It’s supposed to make you mad/sad so you could think about the other choices you could’ve made/consequences of your actions! That’s what we set out to do. We’re artists.” Ok.I’m happy to see modern-day RPG Maker stuff, I really am, and I’m impressed that the team was able to make money off of it but they might wanna grab someone from the NaNoWriMo forums who’s desperate to get their grand works out there next time. Who knows, the gimmick might work. “Budding novelist hopeful teams up with indie vidya designer for passion project. Adam Sessler rises from the grave to promote it until it’s written about in Time Magazine. The medium is finally transcending!” It’s not like anyone’s expecting Walden Simulator or A Sport and a Pastime: The Game.Or, you know, you can just ramble about fate or cry about your ex-girlfriend some more.12/10 would whine about binary moral decisions again.

Posted: January 19, 2015
												I really wanted to like this game; I forced myself to play for almost 15 hours of it and just can’t bring myself into playing anymore. For a story driven game it has shockingly bad writing. The game is about the struggles we face in everyday life, yet the story was completely detached from reality. I mean, there are actions can potently lead to the deaths of multiple people without any repercussions, even though you *spoiler alert* wrote it into a journal which you published into a book!And you know the scene in the dark alley at the start? That’s what got me to keep playing because I wanted to see how the rest of the game tied in to it. Guess what? It doesn’t. Those characters showed up at the very end, and are completely shoed in to justify the first scene.The writing is also extremely pretentious. It spends too much time talking about philosophy of right and wrong, rather than showing through their action of its character. Which is a wasted opportunity, as many characters has potential for development (like Mark). The saying “show, don’t tell” really applies here.The gameplay is pretty much non- existence. Which is fine in “To the Moon” (another story-driven rpg-maker game), because it’s short and to the point. While in this game, I spend 15 hours in this game and still haven’t finished it (I watched a let’s play if you are wondering how I know the ending). It is drawn out and tedious, which would have been okay if the story was good, but it wasn’t.All this would have been forgivable if the developers weren’t so ♥♥♥♥ing pleased with themselves. It’s okay to be proud of your work; it’s also okay put yourself in the game as a character.  What isn’t okay is *spoiler alert* to have a book in the game called “Always Sometimes Monsters” and calling it a masterpiece, and saying that “nothing captures the human spirit quite so well” which it clearly doesn’t, and of yourself show up to offer the author  1 million dollars to turn it into a game.With all that said I hope they learn their lesson and make a better game next time, games like this are few and far between.

Posted: December 23, 2014
												My overall opinion: A pretty good game, it won't be liked by some people but I gotta say the story and the choices you make/say really did feel like a real choice and the ending wasn't set in stone and there are quite a few ways your journey may end earlier or differently(WARNING! THERE ARE SOME HINTED SPOILERS!)(This Is Just My Own Personal Opinion And How I Felt The Game Was To Me And You Might Feel Different To My Point Of View So Please Be Nice Kay? =)It wasn't a game where you can just get the best ending by just rushing to the end and picking the right dialog, it was focused on choices and life decisions that can cause your own story to end suddenly by taking the wrong turn in life. There are some flaws that I felt made the game feel annoying at some points like the boxing minigame or earning enough income in a short time open up another dialog option later in the story but without knowing all this beforehand you'll be left with just one thing, your own personal choice. (and this is without being a cheat and reading a how-to guide!)The epilogue felt open ended and you cannot revisit the previous town/cities to check up on how they are all doing and your main love interest (if you choose to persue it) simply locks him/herself in a room and you end up having a limit set of options you could do.I truely wished there was abit more to the story in the epilogue, I kinda felt cheated after going through everything just to have my main love interest lock him/herself in so I cannot see or talk to him/her and having it end just like that because I felt there could be abit more story between the main character and the love interest rather than relying mostly on flashback/dreams and maybe having them go together to revisit the town/cities the main character have gone to and see where it goes from there.Heres hoping for dlc or a sequel! but I doubt they'd do that, happens too often~ =P Anyways, this is a good game in which I will play again to see what else it has to offer and the main theme of the game is probably the choice in life and maybe something else =P , I hope you enjoy it if you do buy the game, its total recommended game to get!

Posted: January 12, 2015
												This game is like no game I have ever dream to play. It's like a life simulator. It has a dark-ish general story and all, like most games, but you get to decide how to get there. I know, I know. You heard that before, right? Well I will honestly say that this game actually achieves that idea in a way where it makes you think about your life and how you want to live it. I dream to make games like this. It takes you on a journey you (Hopefully) won't forget. You get to pick your main character and his/her love interests (which is a great design and makes you connect to your character more). If you like story driven games, this is for you and I suggest giving it a playthrough (If not more, because trust me, you will want to play it again to see if you can get a different ending or maybe make a better choice then you did before). This game will start with a confusing beginning but it'll all make sense at the end. Now this game does have a couple of cons that I have to state at least. This game is heavily driven on text. If you're not a big fan of reading, you might want to stray away from this game. You will not appreciate it all if you can't appreciate the text. Now that being said, I did spot a FEW mistakes in the spelling and some mishaps on pronouns. For the grammar nazis out there, I just laying that out there. But for a game that probably has over 5000 words in it, 1 or 2 mistakes is just being human, or just being sometimes monsters... SORRY! Had to throw that somewhere in there!To shorten this up though, I'll just make a pros and cons list:Pros:+A great story that leaves you thinking about your life+Choices that make an impact on you+Humorous at times+Well designed (for a RPG Maker game)+Great CharactersCons:-Few Spelling/Grammar errors-My ending made me feel the feels! ♥♥♥♥ you for your feels!Rating:8\10

Posted: January 13, 2015
												I don't usually consider RPG maker games worth spending actual money on, but this game is a glorious exception. I found the characters and the story are both engaging and surprising easy to become invested in. All the different choices give the game excellent replay value, as well as constantly provoking thought on a multitude of ethical issues. The game isn't wihtout fault, random one time mini games can be a rather jarring change of tone, and particularly frustrating when you fail and don't get a chance to redo them. Plus the pace drops significantly when quests run dry in a town and you're left scraping up money for transport to the next town, which can be rather tedious and ends up kicking your immersion right in the balls.Even with those minor issues I still think this is an amazing game and highly recomend plaing it to anyone who has yet to do so.

Posted: January 13, 2015
												Beautiful, well-crafted storytelling: at least for the first two thirds of the game. Worth playing in a single marathon-style sitting for the immersion. Depending on your choices, you may be left re-evaluating your life afterwards, as ASM does not pull its punches.Disappointed with some of the late-game scenes, particularly the flashback to the big break-up. The entire game had been foreshadowing some big way in which my character ♥♥♥♥ed up which made his lover leave, but the actual break-up was very melodramatic and heavy-handed. Also, the inclusion of the developers themselves as minor characters was a nice Easter egg throughout the game, but their post-game scene took the joke too far, spoiling the intensity of the final sequence with a self-indulgent and amateurish cameo. In spite of this, the narrative was overall very solid and complex, and it was easy to immerse myself in my main character.More games like this please.

												This game have an interesting prologue. You lost your love, your job, and even your home at the beginning of the game, and you will have to do whatever you can to get them back. This game is all about choice and consequence. How far would you go to get the life you want?There're lots to do in game. Trying to figure out how to maxmize profit can be interesting. Trying to make different choices and see how things turn out differently is also what make this kind of games interesting too.Although I think the game is fun as a whole, I feel that the character development is weak. Sure they are all interesting, but they are not convincing. To a certain degree, I don't see how the 'past story' can explain or to support the development of the later story. I'm confused and question the actions/reactions of the main characters later in the game. There are so many gaps you have to fill in yourself. Posted: May 3, 2015
												It's an RPG Maker game so you already know it offers the most basic of gameplay in an .exe that hopefully works without having to change some properties. Can't say anything new about that or recommend it to people who are tired with those types of Verge RPG programs from way back. The main draw for this one is its choose-your-own-adventure story system. Unfortunately, that means it had better be written well to be worth $10. Same goes for the $5 soundtrack, which is also too boring and uninspiring to be worth it.Gamers have a very low bar for what’s considered good writing, it seems. No achievement for shooting that first long-winded bum who kept prattling on about choice? C’mon, we were supposed to not hate that dialogue? The biggest problem with moral dilemma stories written by gamers is that it’s so obvious what the intended choice is. They all think the same. Besides, when you have the choice between “Well, I guess you’re right if you really think about it” and “Get the ♥♥♥♥ out of here, I’m not an awful person ugh,” it’s not hard to figure out which path the writer’s hoping you choose, especially since there’s always a trigger involved. Sex? Kinda sketchy. Drugs? Tools of the devil. Old people? Gotta respect ‘em. Do I steal the game dev’s money or do I leave it alone? I wonder which one results in the Game Over.“It’s supposed to make you mad/sad so you could think about the other choices you could’ve made/consequences of your actions! That’s what we set out to do. We’re artists.” Ok.I’m happy to see modern-day RPG Maker stuff, I really am, and I’m impressed that the team was able to make money off of it but they might wanna grab someone from the NaNoWriMo forums who’s desperate to get their grand works out there next time. Who knows, the gimmick might work. “Budding novelist hopeful teams up with indie vidya designer for passion project. Adam Sessler rises from the grave to promote it until it’s written about in Time Magazine. The medium is finally transcending!” It’s not like anyone’s expecting Walden Simulator or A Sport and a Pastime: The Game.Or, you know, you can just ramble about fate or cry about your ex-girlfriend some more.12/10 would whine about binary moral decisions again.

												A well crafted and enjoyable RPG, Always Sometimes Monsters is a nice getaway from what many might conceive to be a bland market. It has quirks and charms that you don't find in many games, and the gameplay is well paced and not overwhelmingly long, leaving the player content at the end. Music and sound are good, dialogue tends to be pretty decent, and the storyline is almost believable - again, something reasonably rare for a game.Only real fault I can find is that it may take a few hours of gameplay to pull you in, but I'd say it's worth it for the finished product. 7/10 for sure

Posted: February 13, 2015
												Must play for:- people who are sick with RPG Maker games in fantasy setting,- people who thinks every RPG Maker game is bad.Personally I don't care how game was made - if it's engine written from begin to end by devs or any version of RPG Maker, all of this is not important. What really matter is content and Always Sometimes Monsters doesn't fail in that matter. What is this game about? In short: it's about player, which means you. Every choice brings consequences. How the story will go and how will it end - it depend only on you and what you would do in some situations. It's not some kind of epic story, it's not also some masterpiece that will leave you speechless while playing or ending it - it's just a nice game full of things that might give you some thoughts, or not, and you will think it's trying to be something more than it is. There is a demo version of game, so give it a try and decide for yourself if you want to continue this story or not. I don't regret time spending playing Always Sometimes Monsters. In fact, I would gladly play more story-driven games.

Posted: August 21, 2014
												If given four words to describe the contents of Always Sometimes Monsters, they would all happen to begin with the letter 'C':  Coincidence, circumstance, choice, and consequence.  Unfortunately, if I were to give a letter grade to the overall game and my experience, I would have to be quite forgiving to remain using the letter 'C'.A "life simulator" if you will, this is a game that plants you into a world where your hopes and dreams haven't proceeded as planned.  In a time where it has become a struggle to earn enough money to pay for food or keep a roof over your head, you find yourself invited to a wedding in a distant city.  You are tasked to find your way there within a month's time, and along the road many scenarios and options are presented to tailor your experience in exactly how you will (or will not) achieve your goal.The freedom of choice is apparent upon starting the game and persists throughout to an extent.  Sacrifice to help a friend or be selfish?  Take sides with party X or organization Y?  Take the high road or the low?  Many situations might give you pause to stop and consider your choices before committing.  Do you want to retain moral character or will the means justify the ends?  All of it is left to you as the player and will ultimately decide your fate.In the end, however, I was left rather unsatistfied with the game as a whole.  I felt as though my personal choices led to the same general path I might have ended up at had I gone the opposite direction.  Sure, one or two characters would have had different opinions of who I was in the end, maybe they'd be there in the final scene or maybe not.  But what impact did I have on the world?  ...Very little, it seems.  I chose to go with more of an upstanding citizen and aide (though not in EVERY scenario, hence the appropriate title), and as a result the choices seemed rote.  As a game that asks you to make difficult decisions, there was never a moment where I felt like I NEEDED to break out of the role I had chosen.  It felt no different to a Mass Effect game: if you play a paragon character, you make paragon choices in just about every situation.  Therefore, for a game all about choices and consequences, Always Sometimes Monsters rarely presented anything that felt meaningful.  As for the "game" part of the game, it's pretty messy and rarely flows well.  Conversations are held up and constantly prolonged with bubbles floating above characters' heads displaying elipses or hearts or exclamation points, none of which can be hurried with button presses or disabled in the options.  Just as disrupting is a big clock that pops up and remains on screen for at least a full five seconds whenever each "stage" of the day transitions from one to the next.And the mini-games.  OH, the mini-games.  Some exist to reward you in the form of money or key items.  Some are there just to spice up the world and give you something else to do off the beaten path.  However, ALL of them are rather monotonous, if not downright frustrating from time to time.  Need to puzzle out a mini-game over five or ten minutes for some cash once, that's okay.  Need to repeat that same puzzle a dozen times with hardly any variables changing, each lasting the same five to ten minutes?  It's boring and tedious.  I spent twelve hours in the game, and I would have been much more satisfied with the experience if it were cut in half.  ...At a bare minimum.  And when a mini-game causes you to savescum a few dozen times, there's something wrong.  This is a piece of work that asks you to consider your choices and their consequences, so its aim has gone awry when you're in a postion where you find yourself quitting and reloading to go back to previous saves.Due to the nature of how this game plays with its choices, I know that I missed a lot of content by making the decisions I did.  There's a lot left to see and experience.  Normally I'd be gung ho to get right back into it to see everything I could.  ...But not with Always Sometimes Monsters.  I didn't finish it excitedly to see what ending might unfold; I finished it over a few play sessions, each start more and more begrudgingly, only to get it done and out of the way.  I was not invested in my character or the world or the emotions it tried (and failed) to stir within me.  I was only pushing buttons to see what the game had to offer, and in the end I wasn't all that interested, surprised, or all that enthralled.  For a "cerebral" game that wanted me to think or care, it failed with me.   It doesn't stand up to similar "head space" games.  Gone Home made me curious and sympathetic.  To The Moon gave me wonder, tugged at my heart, and literally brought me to tears of joy and sadness simultaneously.  ...Always Sometimes Monsters far too often made me slump in my chair, toss back my head and roll my eyes, and caused me to breathe out grunts of annoyance and exasperation. Thus, I can't recommend it.  Sorry, Vagabond Dogs.  I wanted to like it.  It just didn't do it for me.

Posted: August 17, 2014
												I lit a camp fire for some old coot, it gave me the option to walk on it and I died horribly - 10/10In all seriousness though I would give it closer to a 6/10, with only a soft-recommend due to some game design choices.It's a hard game to point out my exact reason for the just slightly above average score without getting into spoilers. The story is really the reason to play this and how choice in it was handled at certain points (in terms of game design) are why I had to take points away.Suffice it to say it was a geniunely interesting journey, that is designed in such a way to turn the decisions you made throughout the game into a meaningless illusion, all the while it sold itself on the idea that it was doing the opposite.Anything that truly determines the final outcome happens within the last few moments and you're given full control in choosing them right then and there regardless of past actions.That is a pretty major flaw for this sort of game in my opinion. It makes everything else you had given serious thought and consideration into choosing pretty much pointless.You could theoretically experience all endings on a single playthrough if you save before these final choice moments, then reloading and playing the last 10-20min~ while choosing different combinations of options "A or B" instead.That's really not what the game makes itself out to be while you're going through it all, and all things considered I found that fairly disapointing to discover.Bottom line is; It creates the illusion of your choices throughout the entire game mattering and being the cause of your end result. However that is just not how it plays out or how it was designed to work, which is unfortunate since it would otherwise be the thought provoking work of art many people claim it to be.

												Amazing game!It's a very dramatic and emotional kind of game. The money I spent on getting this game was worth every dollar.Almost Sometimes Monsters revolves around  you , or your character. You are faced with many choices that are obvious and hidden. The game touched some very sensitive issues which is really unique and sometimes confronting.Almost Sometimes Monsters focus on the bad side, the flaws of the world, so don't expect the typical happily ever after or kiss in the sunset. When I played the game, I knew there were some really disturbing scenes, but I didn't think that it would make me really uncomfortable, whilst playing the game I felt that I grew closer to the characters, the situations, the consequences.My favourite part of the game is not the tragedy, but the freedom and the many paths you could take. It's like playing a game made by Telltale Games mixed with Rockstar games. I played this game without getting any NPCs killed...I think...Actually there's this one jerk who really ticked me off, but I regretted it afterwards.If you like RPGs, drama, violence, and tragedy then this is the game for you! I can't wait for a new game (hopefully not disappointing) from you Vagabond Dogs! ♥

Posted: August 16, 2014
												This isn't like some triple A. You don't make choices buy clicking a button. You don't make choices by choosing from two. You make choices with your money and your time, similar to Papers Please.This is a phenomanal game in which you, having been kicked out your apartment with little money to your name, must journey across the country to attend the wedding of your ex and win them back. I haven't beaten this game yet, but I'm a chunk of the way through. I think I've pretty much won. I guarantee you I haven't.The choices you make define who you are. I killed a woman, or put her life in serious risk, for $30 towards my salvation. I fell on and killed a man attempting to destroy a city, all for money I never got. I made children watch their father die for a car. I made some horrible choices. Consequnce is real in this game. The choices I made I never believed would result in death. People are dead because I need to go across the country. When you are desperate, every choice you make seems to harm those around you.Always Sometimse Monsters is scary. It's not a horror game, but its scary because it explorers the consequnces of our actions. My character may starve because I payed my rent, for an apartment I never even needed. I just felt it was the right choice.The choices we make define who we are. In Always Sometimes Monsters, it's a journey of self discovery.

Posted: January 19, 2015
												I really wanted to like this game; I forced myself to play for almost 15 hours of it and just can’t bring myself into playing anymore. For a story driven game it has shockingly bad writing. The game is about the struggles we face in everyday life, yet the story was completely detached from reality. I mean, there are actions can potently lead to the deaths of multiple people without any repercussions, even though you *spoiler alert* wrote it into a journal which you published into a book!And you know the scene in the dark alley at the start? That’s what got me to keep playing because I wanted to see how the rest of the game tied in to it. Guess what? It doesn’t. Those characters showed up at the very end, and are completely shoed in to justify the first scene.The writing is also extremely pretentious. It spends too much time talking about philosophy of right and wrong, rather than showing through their action of its character. Which is a wasted opportunity, as many characters has potential for development (like Mark). The saying “show, don’t tell” really applies here.The gameplay is pretty much non- existence. Which is fine in “To the Moon” (another story-driven rpg-maker game), because it’s short and to the point. While in this game, I spend 15 hours in this game and still haven’t finished it (I watched a let’s play if you are wondering how I know the ending). It is drawn out and tedious, which would have been okay if the story was good, but it wasn’t.All this would have been forgivable if the developers weren’t so ♥♥♥♥ing pleased with themselves. It’s okay to be proud of your work; it’s also okay put yourself in the game as a character.  What isn’t okay is *spoiler alert* to have a book in the game called “Always Sometimes Monsters” and calling it a masterpiece, and saying that “nothing captures the human spirit quite so well” which it clearly doesn’t, and of yourself show up to offer the author  1 million dollars to turn it into a game.With all that said I hope they learn their lesson and make a better game next time, games like this are few and far between.
