												Reading the synopsis for Always Sometimes Monsters I thought it was the coolest thing, since I'm a huge fan of simulation and create your own destiny games. Started out pretty good, and went downhill after about 2 hours.It just didn't deliver as much as I thought it would. It was tedious, unbelievable, and unsatisfying .Let's start off with "tedious". To make money, there are various jobs in the game. Jobs like packing meat or tofu into boxes, or sorting weed or other plants into baggies. And let me tell you, they are no fun. Most people know of the infamous packing boxes into a truck scene. You could literally spend about 25 minutes going back and forth putting these boxes into the truck, and if you think "Let's see what happens when I get to 100!" you will be very disappointed, my friend.For the "unbelievable" part, I just mean that some positions you're put in don't make sense. Really. This game tries to be dramatic and put you in "hazardous" situations, but it just comes off like it's trying too hard. Like it really wants to make your character's life miserable. And you know how this game is basically about you trying to get to your ex's wedding? There's a plot twist (a pretty obvious one) that is totally unbelievable, as in, unrealistic. If you really look at the characters' backgrounds, it doesn't make sense. Seems like it's just there for the sake of having a plot twist.Now for the unsatisfying ending, no spoilers. Like I said, I love games where the decisions you make affect the story, but in the end, no matter what you do you'll get the bad ending (and that's not a spoiler. You actually start off at the end of the game). I played several times to see all possible different endings, and even when I did everything to get myself the best possible ending, I still ended up homeless. I just don't understand.Don't get me wrong, I don't regret buying this game. I still play it every now and then. It's got it's perks as a game with a lot of stuff to do and decision to make. I'm just adding some criticism since all the other comments here seem to be pretty positive.Just saying, expect to get frustrated and question a lot of things.

Posted: December 4, 2014
												Always Sometimes Monsters is an RPG developed by Vagabond Dog to simulate survival in modern society whilst driving forward a constant storyline revolving around your chosen character and partner that you choose at the beginning of the game. The responsibility of choosing your own way in life and making important decisions really grabbed my attention when playing through this. It is not your average RPG in which you play a linear story making choices that don't necessarily affect the state of the world and the relationships you have with the people in it, Infact, the choices you make will definately affect the world around you and the way that you are treated by other characters definately towards the end of the game.The visuals are pretty standard for an RPG of this type, but the attention to detail is definately worth a mention, If you want an interesting visual experience and a great story, this game can definately provide you with both. There are a few graphical problems, particularly with the Hospital Lobby area, the food plates seem to be hovering in mid air and are being eaten by people standing at the ends of the table instead of being sat at it, I don't know if this is a known problem, or if vagabond intend to deal with it, but it isn't an experience ruiner for sure, so don't let it affect your opinion too badly.The music in this game is incredibly atmospheric, and provides a lot of mood setting for the particular towns and areas. The Laser Destroyer Team did a great job on it and they should be proud of the masterpieces that they produced. One of my favourite tracks is 'Hit the Town', and I suggest you give those a listen if you're into 8-bit themes.TOTALS:Graphics: 6/10Sound: 9/10Story: 9.5/10 (Absolutely insanely good, but not perfect in every way)Polised? --Couple of minor scratches 8/1032.5/40Overall experience rating: Garunteed memorable game!"RPG lovers will love such a personal and exciting experience ;3" - Bunnieth

Posted: January 12, 2015
												This game is like no game I have ever dream to play. It's like a life simulator. It has a dark-ish general story and all, like most games, but you get to decide how to get there. I know, I know. You heard that before, right? Well I will honestly say that this game actually achieves that idea in a way where it makes you think about your life and how you want to live it. I dream to make games like this. It takes you on a journey you (Hopefully) won't forget. You get to pick your main character and his/her love interests (which is a great design and makes you connect to your character more). If you like story driven games, this is for you and I suggest giving it a playthrough (If not more, because trust me, you will want to play it again to see if you can get a different ending or maybe make a better choice then you did before). This game will start with a confusing beginning but it'll all make sense at the end. Now this game does have a couple of cons that I have to state at least. This game is heavily driven on text. If you're not a big fan of reading, you might want to stray away from this game. You will not appreciate it all if you can't appreciate the text. Now that being said, I did spot a FEW mistakes in the spelling and some mishaps on pronouns. For the grammar nazis out there, I just laying that out there. But for a game that probably has over 5000 words in it, 1 or 2 mistakes is just being human, or just being sometimes monsters... SORRY! Had to throw that somewhere in there!To shorten this up though, I'll just make a pros and cons list:Pros:+A great story that leaves you thinking about your life+Choices that make an impact on you+Humorous at times+Well designed (for a RPG Maker game)+Great CharactersCons:-Few Spelling/Grammar errors-My ending made me feel the feels! ♥♥♥♥ you for your feels!Rating:8\10

The collectible indie figures in the game have no impact/achievement/worth. And the controls aren't listed in the game for some reason (esc is the back button)-Underwhelming endings or endings that don't really make sense.-Despite multiple endings, little replayability since most of the game will be the same despite your choicesIt's worth trying out if you got it off the humble bundle or on a great sale, but otherwise I'd skip it

Posted: November 24, 2014
												Just now found out about stuff after the credits. So everything below this was before that. Sorry for the rush, I couldn't help it. Okay so the stuff after the credits is just minigames. Absolutely love it. I got this a while back, but never played it. I ended up deleting it from my computer until I saw someone play the beginning and decided to reinstall and play it. I'm glad I did. I don't remember exactly when, but I think I started around 5pm and played until about 11am, near the end of the game. I just now finished it, and I'm going to be replaying it from the start soon, after I see how the ending is affected by a certain choice at the end... As for an actual "review," here we go:Always Sometimes Monsters isn't like whatever you're thinking it is. The game opens on a scene where you meet someone in a dark alley as you're attempting to quit your job as a contract killer. If you choose to listen, then you're told a brilliant story of the concept of choice, and an interesting tale of what it means to love someone. You'll be spending a lot of time doing odd jobs and making choices. In fact, those are the two main things in the game. There are some minigames, but they're all very easy and simple. Which is good, it keeps your focus on the story. The themes and choices in the game can range from incredibly dark to light hearted, though much of that is determined by you. I can't give this game a high enough recommendation. If nothing else, the humor and view points presented in the game make it worth playing through the end. My only complaint is that the in-story twist and the out of story twist are both too obvious, but that never really takes away from the experience. Though it does make me want to go back to that one choice and see what happens. The inclusion of the developers is a great touch, especially the Dubstown building. Again, I can't recommend this game enough. I absolutely love it and I feel like anyone who plays it will come away with something, even if they don't like Always Sometimes Monsters. Lastly, as just a note about something, at the very end of the story, "his" was said in reference to Sam, even though she was female at the time.

Posted: August 21, 2014
												If given four words to describe the contents of Always Sometimes Monsters, they would all happen to begin with the letter 'C':  Coincidence, circumstance, choice, and consequence.  Unfortunately, if I were to give a letter grade to the overall game and my experience, I would have to be quite forgiving to remain using the letter 'C'.A "life simulator" if you will, this is a game that plants you into a world where your hopes and dreams haven't proceeded as planned.  In a time where it has become a struggle to earn enough money to pay for food or keep a roof over your head, you find yourself invited to a wedding in a distant city.  You are tasked to find your way there within a month's time, and along the road many scenarios and options are presented to tailor your experience in exactly how you will (or will not) achieve your goal.The freedom of choice is apparent upon starting the game and persists throughout to an extent.  Sacrifice to help a friend or be selfish?  Take sides with party X or organization Y?  Take the high road or the low?  Many situations might give you pause to stop and consider your choices before committing.  Do you want to retain moral character or will the means justify the ends?  All of it is left to you as the player and will ultimately decide your fate.In the end, however, I was left rather unsatistfied with the game as a whole.  I felt as though my personal choices led to the same general path I might have ended up at had I gone the opposite direction.  Sure, one or two characters would have had different opinions of who I was in the end, maybe they'd be there in the final scene or maybe not.  But what impact did I have on the world?  ...Very little, it seems.  I chose to go with more of an upstanding citizen and aide (though not in EVERY scenario, hence the appropriate title), and as a result the choices seemed rote.  As a game that asks you to make difficult decisions, there was never a moment where I felt like I NEEDED to break out of the role I had chosen.  It felt no different to a Mass Effect game: if you play a paragon character, you make paragon choices in just about every situation.  Therefore, for a game all about choices and consequences, Always Sometimes Monsters rarely presented anything that felt meaningful.  As for the "game" part of the game, it's pretty messy and rarely flows well.  Conversations are held up and constantly prolonged with bubbles floating above characters' heads displaying elipses or hearts or exclamation points, none of which can be hurried with button presses or disabled in the options.  Just as disrupting is a big clock that pops up and remains on screen for at least a full five seconds whenever each "stage" of the day transitions from one to the next.And the mini-games.  OH, the mini-games.  Some exist to reward you in the form of money or key items.  Some are there just to spice up the world and give you something else to do off the beaten path.  However, ALL of them are rather monotonous, if not downright frustrating from time to time.  Need to puzzle out a mini-game over five or ten minutes for some cash once, that's okay.  Need to repeat that same puzzle a dozen times with hardly any variables changing, each lasting the same five to ten minutes?  It's boring and tedious.  I spent twelve hours in the game, and I would have been much more satisfied with the experience if it were cut in half.  ...At a bare minimum.  And when a mini-game causes you to savescum a few dozen times, there's something wrong.  This is a piece of work that asks you to consider your choices and their consequences, so its aim has gone awry when you're in a postion where you find yourself quitting and reloading to go back to previous saves.Due to the nature of how this game plays with its choices, I know that I missed a lot of content by making the decisions I did.  There's a lot left to see and experience.  Normally I'd be gung ho to get right back into it to see everything I could.  ...But not with Always Sometimes Monsters.  I didn't finish it excitedly to see what ending might unfold; I finished it over a few play sessions, each start more and more begrudgingly, only to get it done and out of the way.  I was not invested in my character or the world or the emotions it tried (and failed) to stir within me.  I was only pushing buttons to see what the game had to offer, and in the end I wasn't all that interested, surprised, or all that enthralled.  For a "cerebral" game that wanted me to think or care, it failed with me.   It doesn't stand up to similar "head space" games.  Gone Home made me curious and sympathetic.  To The Moon gave me wonder, tugged at my heart, and literally brought me to tears of joy and sadness simultaneously.  ...Always Sometimes Monsters far too often made me slump in my chair, toss back my head and roll my eyes, and caused me to breathe out grunts of annoyance and exasperation. Thus, I can't recommend it.  Sorry, Vagabond Dogs.  I wanted to like it.  It just didn't do it for me.

Posted: October 3, 2015
												Alright, I think it's been enough time since I've played this game to give an accurate review of it. To preface this, I went in with high expectations due to watching Jesse Cox play this game on Youtube, expectations that were MET in the BEGINNING of the game anyway. The game looks good, the writing is solid, and the minigames to get money are fun.... BUUUUT the entire game is hamstrung by a time-constraint that you need to be at your Ex's wedding by a certain time, on top of which the 'variety' of choices you have really boils down to two equally unappealing prospects, which you pick the one which sounds the best. To make matters a bit worse, there aren't even many apparent consequences OF your actions beyond what you can imagine.  That normally wouldn't be a deal-breaker, but then, due to my neurotic nature, I looked up how to best play the game and what I needed to do, willingly spoiling the ending for myself and.... Seriously? The entire point of this game is to go through trials and tribulations so that you might be able to achieve SOMETHING right? But no, spoiler alert: No matter what you do, the ending will suck. That is a deal-breaker for me, when you build up a game that is actually REALLY good starting off, but then you decide to give a bad ending no matter what? That's just... Terrible writing on the dev's part. The game has its moments, and if you're in it for the mini-games, or some of the decisions, then good, but if you are wanting a good ending as a sort of payoff for putting in hard work and becoming attatched to your character, then you'll be in for a big disappointment. Hopefully some people liked this game, and it's a good try for the devs, if they do make any more games, hopefully they'll think ahead and see that setting up every ending as a kick in the groin ISN'T a way to please fans.

Posted: December 5, 2015
												You start off on the bottom.Rock bottom.Your life is in pieces and you set out to put it all back together.And from there, the adventure is up to you.With the theme of desperation always lingering, will you resort to doing immoral things to add some bills to what little money you have?Will you invest some of your precious time into making friends, or would you rather be a lone wolf in the world?How far will you go to win back the love of your life and have a complete restart in your life?There are some choices in this game which I find to be irrelevant, and some mechanics I found to be useless But if we go storywise, I'd consider this as somewhat of a masterpieceIt's not the first of it's kind to have dark themesIt's definitely not clear of useless parts in it's storyBut it opens your eyes a bitIn the numerous towns and cities you go to in your journey, you will see many disturbing things that are actually things that happen in real life There are some characters that you might grow to hate, their sharp tongued, selfish and hypocriticalThey're humanIf theres any word that can summarize my whole take on the plot, it's humanWhether you like it or not you will definitely make choices in this game that would give you second thoughtsAnother thing I'd like to add is how realistic the ending isEven if you try and think you made all the right choices, you're probably going to get the bad endingYou have to work really hard to get a "Good" ending, or at least where your character is happyIt's human in that the end will always leave someone on top and someone rock bottomIt's a human world, and humans are Always Sometimes Monsters

For the most part, I agree with a lot of the negative and Petrel opinions of the game and I don't bring up the well-mentioned issues they bring up. I just add things that annoyed me.****SPOILER WARNING****From the beginning of the game with the hitman and the casino owner/gangster wannabe to the politican election in Beaton to somehow inheriting Mark's car trouble in more then one way and lastly the threating to kill or killing of Sam for a debt she made less than 24 hours ago... all of these issues raise nothing but questions about the story or is just straight up illogical.Why are the hitman and casino wannabe important to the story... why is the opening scene important at all? None of it is need for the dark descent someone has to take at the end and nothing comes of the hitman sudden desire to not be a murderer. If you shoot, the game automatically ends, so what's the point of them and the scene?Why is it necessary for me to get involved with the election in Beaton? I get that doing so speeds up the game, but the fact that a random, powerless, struggling writer from another town comes out of no where and ends up the sole desider of an election. Even if you choose to not go through with it, your still deciding the outcome. That's just ridiculous. Could have used this time to flesh out Larry and his wife, which is far more interesting and it would be more believable for your character to solve that issue as well. ( the vent thing is just wrong as wel).Why do you inherit Mark's car problem? Why would he volunteer to help when he didn't have the means to help?... Why does this section of the game exist when you could GO WITH LARRY, who's knows your going to the wedding, and is going himself? nuff said.Why does the Sam debt dilemma exist? She just got the debt. I get that it's to start drama, but if you wanted to start drama, make Sam a cheater that gets caught or make his/her try to steal the journal for just his/her own selfish gain or to ruin you out of spite for dating the ex they liked in the first place. Hell it can stay the way it is. Just make a scene where he/she has to tell the ex about it and the gamer could either be the bigger person and help smooth things over or use the opportunity to raise hell or something.All in all, the game is ok despite these and many other immersion breaking things going on. I recommend it for it's general concept is refreshing, but you might want to turn your brain off to fully enjoy.P.S. Dev cameos are fun, but it's a bit over done in this game.

												This game was like playing a visual novel disguised as an RPG, which wasn't a bad thing at all. A couple parts feel a little farm-y, like the boxing and casino minigames towards the end, but overall was very enjoyable on my first playthrough.By the time you finish the game, at least the first time, odds are you've been able to guess the ending, but that doesn't make the choices feel any less impactful. In fact, for me, it directly influenced my endgame choices.I definitely enjoyed playing it through, and even though I know how it goes, I'll be going for another few playthroughs just to see how my decisions change the gameplay and ending.Overall, this game is probably good for at most 4 or 5 playthroughs if you're just looking to see the endings, but there are so many little subtle things that you can experience that don't directly impact gameplay... they're more of little side-events that you get to see, so there's definitely still room to enjoy the game beyond "I've seen all the endings" and I'll probably play a few more times through, just to explore... then I'll put the game away for a while until it feels fresh again, which I think it will. That's part of the beauty I see in this game: almost anyone will be able to relate at least somehow to the events that play out.It's a shining testament to what people can create with the RPG Maker tool with a bit of creativity and a unique approach to game design.

Posted: October 6, 2015
												I wrote an amazingly long review that glitched out and didn't post, so I'll keep it brief.DISCLAIMER: I played the game with a friend the whole way through, and we were goofing off from the very beginning.  That might color my views a little bit.This game was responsible for both my best experience in gaming, and the hardest I had ever laughed at anything.This game is not a good story-driven game.  The choices you would expect to matter don't, and the choices you would expect not to matter do.  For example, you can steal from a rich old woman who trusted you or literally murder a man in broad daylight with no consequences, but selling a dog results in it being trained as a boxing animal that you have to fight later on, which makes things much, much harder.The game doesn't give you enough time with it's characters to really feel bad for them.  This makes sense given the setting of the game, but it's still a point against.  You need to develop a character if you want people to appreciate it when they get broken down.  You can't just introduce characters and then instantly have them kill themselves or get shot and expect me to feel sorry.  If I felt sorry for those sorts, then I would also feel sorry for every random enemy I shot in an FPS.It never made me feel sadness or remorse even though it constantly tried.  In fact, it was how hard it tried that made me laugh most of the time.  Some parts are obviously intentionally funny, and are funny due to being outright ridiculous, but most of the games humor came from it trying way too hard to be tragic in a way that made me feel like I was laughing with the game, not at it.  It is hard to explain.There's no way to describe all the times the game made me laugh without spoiling it, and even then, it needs context for you to really understand.If the developers were trying to make an amazing comedy, they succeeded and are absolutely brilliant.  Humor comes from the unexpected, and this game is paced and marketed perfectly for that.  If you think about the hardest you have ever laughed, chances are you aren't thinking of a joke a comedian told.  You expect comedians to be funny, and you expect funny games to be funny.  You expect sitcoms to be funny.  That expectation lowers the potential.  It can make you laugh, but not quite as much as things that aren't supposed to be funny.If this game was developed to be funny, it is the greatest work of comedy ever devised.It has just the right amount of soul-crushing, boring gameplay where nothing interesting really happens.  The majority of the game is walking through towns and talking to characters you will never see again, about things that don't really matter.  It's that drought of fun that makes the bright spots all the better.I can't even tell if it was developed to be funny or to be an interesting story.  The perfection of the pacing leads me to believe its supposed to be funny, but the marketing, and the amount of people who apparently didn't think of it as a hilarious experience make me think that maybe it wasn't supposed to be that way.  Maybe I only think of it that way because I played it with a friend the whole way through and got it for free off of a humble bundle without really knowing what it was or what it was supposed to be.In short:  Play it with a friend and expect nothing.  Forget you ever read this.  You can use skype screen share while the game is in windowed mode to play it with a friend and talk at the same time, that's what we did.  (sorry steam but your steaming service is bad at the time of this review)If you do that, you might just have as much fun as I did, which will make it well worth two feet of subway sandwiches.

Posted: June 24, 2015
												Always Sometimes Monsters is an intriguing game where your decisions impact the narrative. While not an entirely new concept, this game manages to keep things interesting most of the time. Gameplay The gameplay in Always Sometimes Monsters is primarily about making choices. In the beginning of the game, you choose your character by deciding who to toast with at a party, and then choose your love interest by going to the balcony and talking with one of the many characters. It makes character selection more interesting than just picking from a menu. Also, you are able to choose from a diverse group of male/female characters and can choose to be either heterosexual or homosexual.There is an in-game clock of sorts that breaks the day up into 3 parts - morning, afternoon, and night. You can do one job/event per time of day, and some tasks require a certain time of day. After completing the task, that part of the day is automatically over. This is where making choices comes into play. You have to decide what you are going to do for each segment of the day, and the choices you make during those jobs and events affect the way the story unfolds. You have 30 in-game days to reach a particular destination (I won't spoil what that is, since it is a major part of the story).There are some mini-games as well, but to be honest, they were not too interesting to me. I tried each one once or twice, but I did not have the desire to revisit them. Lastly, there are optional figures to collect that feature characters from various indie games, though I'm not sure if they serve a purpose other than to be collected for fun (they can be sold to the pawn shop for a little extra money, but I preferred to keep them in my collection). Story I won't spoil anything, but the actual game starts one year after the party I mentioned previously where you select your character. You are basically trying to get your life back on track. There are several main areas in the game, and each has its own story and set of quests you will need to do in order to make it to the next area. This is unfortunately where the game is hit-or-miss, since it is a story-driven game. Some characters and events are intriguing, while others just simply are not (at least in my opinion). However, keep in mind that I only played through the game once, so my choices may not have led to all of the most interesting events.Dialogue is good about 70% of the time, but the rest of it is not quite at the same level of quality. It feels like certain parts are trying to be very mature, but they don't always quite hit the mark. It's not terrible by any means, but just something I wanted to point out. There are also some spelling and grammar mistakes that I encountered on more than a few occasions. It's not a deal-breaker, but those kinds of mistakes sometimes took me out of the moment. I understand that this is an indie game and it's not easy to find every little mistake during the development process, though. Sound The songs are pretty cool for the most part - simple yet catchy electronic music. Be aware that there are some songs that got annoying after a while, but only if I was in a particular area for an extended period of time. If you really love that type of music, you may not find it to be too annoying. I just felt like there was a lack of variety. The sound effects were fine and I have no complaints about them. Conclusion Despite its flaws, I do recommend this game. It was made using RPG Maker, and as someone who has used those tools before, I must say that it is impressive what these developers were able to do with it. If you enjoy story-driven games where your choices matter, then Always Sometimes Monsters is worth your time.

Posted: December 11, 2014
												Reading the synopsis for Always Sometimes Monsters I thought it was the coolest thing, since I'm a huge fan of simulation and create your own destiny games. Started out pretty good, and went downhill after about 2 hours.It just didn't deliver as much as I thought it would. It was tedious, unbelievable, and unsatisfying .Let's start off with "tedious". To make money, there are various jobs in the game. Jobs like packing meat or tofu into boxes, or sorting weed or other plants into baggies. And let me tell you, they are no fun. Most people know of the infamous packing boxes into a truck scene. You could literally spend about 25 minutes going back and forth putting these boxes into the truck, and if you think "Let's see what happens when I get to 100!" you will be very disappointed, my friend.For the "unbelievable" part, I just mean that some positions you're put in don't make sense. Really. This game tries to be dramatic and put you in "hazardous" situations, but it just comes off like it's trying too hard. Like it really wants to make your character's life miserable. And you know how this game is basically about you trying to get to your ex's wedding? There's a plot twist (a pretty obvious one) that is totally unbelievable, as in, unrealistic. If you really look at the characters' backgrounds, it doesn't make sense. Seems like it's just there for the sake of having a plot twist.Now for the unsatisfying ending, no spoilers. Like I said, I love games where the decisions you make affect the story, but in the end, no matter what you do you'll get the bad ending (and that's not a spoiler. You actually start off at the end of the game). I played several times to see all possible different endings, and even when I did everything to get myself the best possible ending, I still ended up homeless. I just don't understand.Don't get me wrong, I don't regret buying this game. I still play it every now and then. It's got it's perks as a game with a lot of stuff to do and decision to make. I'm just adding some criticism since all the other comments here seem to be pretty positive.Just saying, expect to get frustrated and question a lot of things.

Posted: December 10, 2014
												I've really tried to enjoy this game, specially after reading so many positive reviews about it. I enjoy story based games, and the premise sounded promising enough to catch my attention. But I can't do it, I can't keep going on.I'll start by saying that I don't mind the graphics, or the RPG-Maker, or the really crappy sound effects. And if I have to point out something positive, I'll say that the music is pretty decent. But the story... It tries to hook you up in a plot of moral dilemmas and hard choices, about a young person out of luck, alone in the cold, uncaring world. But every time the game was about to catch me in it, a blatant change of tone, terrible inconsistencies would break any immersion I was having. The game tries to be dramatic and emotional, but any kind of tension is completely diluted by continuous 4th wall breakings, silly jokes and unnecessary collectables.It also tries to sell you that your decisions matter, but they hardly do. For example, at one point, you might not have enough money to pay for a room, and find yourself sleeping in the streets. Which at first I thought it'd be terrible and a real handicap while trying to find a job and get back on my feet, turned to have absolutely no consequences.  You'd think that sleeping under the stars, among the hobos, not being able to take showers or change your clothes would have any negative effects in your health or social status, but no. You search for food in a trash can, heat it up in a burning barrel and sleep on a dirty mattress in a creepy alley, and then go to work as a top notch reporter in the local newspaper, then go dance at the expensive club at night. Just before you go back to sleep to your hobo alley. By the time I had enough money to rent a room, I didn't even consider doing it, because there was no point in doing so, at least, that I could see!And on top of that, to get money, you have to do little mini games that are absolutely tedious. And I've played Papers, Please, and Cart Life, games that played on routine and struggling with your life every day, and enjoyed it. I couldn't keep playing Always Sometimes Monsters.

Posted: May 31, 2015
												This game is basically a non-combat interactive story where you can make a lot of choices that will have consequences, so on the game has multiple endings. I really like those type of games and I think it's pretty well done in this one. The game can be pretty dark, but that's one of the reasons as to why I like it even more. It really shows that life isn't all roses and it does bring across several messages. Even though those things are not always perceived the same way by people, nor can I agree with all of them. But that's an entirely different matter. The story was interesting enough to keep me wanting to play and near the end of the game I'd actually gotten attached to my character, which is always a good sign. The game comes with many mini-games for jobs and also in the shape of arcade video games your character can play which I thought was a nice touch and I enjoyed them, although I've seen people say they found the jobs tedious to do. Regardless from that possibly being the case for people, I still think it's not something that would stand in the way of enjoying this game for all it's other aspects. Overall this is a pretty brilliantly composed game, especially considering it was made in RPG-maker by a small studio of indie-developers.

Posted: June 8, 2015
												Fantastic game that I've played many times over. You feel real attachment to not only your own character and the ♥♥♥♥ they have to go through, but quite inexplicably, you find yourself yearning to be reunited with your character's ex, which I found surprising considering how little is revealed about them until later in the story. You just know from the moment you start a new game that the person you choose to play and their other half (also chosen by you) are meant to be together and that's it. Perhaps that's what it is to be human...but then humans (like the title of the game suggests) are always sometimes monsters. Sometimes you might find yourself doing bad things, for yourself, to try and achieve a greater good that you are aiming for. This game lets you explore that concept and it is utterly captivating. I hope Vagabond Dog do more games like this, because it will be an instant buy from me.

Posted: June 10, 2015
												OK this game is good. Its real good. However I understand that its not for everybody. First when it says it's story driving, it ain't kidding. The only form of gameplay in this game is just talking to people, walking around, and answering prompts. However, it doesn't lessen from the story at all. In fact, it actually adds to it. Without the need to focus on combat mechanics and such, the writing takes the centerstage and it deserves it. The story starts out with you trying to get your lover back. In a month. Before they get married. Its got heartwarming moments and characters and some pretty funny dialouge. Its choices are pretty heavy too. Some may seem unfair and sometimes the outcomes can seem a bit extreame but the story does a great job by making you feel like you have all the control for most of the game. My only problem with the game is that for you to get the good ending you basically have to look it up. There is a requirment you must reach before you go to the end zone and no one tells you about it at all and there is no way to actually know about it (as far as i am concerned). I suggest that if you do want to get the good ending you are going to have to look only that part up. The rest is up to you. I enjoyed it a lot and I look forward to vagabond dog's future games. I hope they have some soon.

Posted: September 10, 2015
												This is one of those that I wish Steam allowed for more than a rigid "yes or no" for reviews. I, personally, have problems liking this game and getting immersed enough with the story and mechanics (which actually at some points seemed off putting and monotonous) Of course it's hard not to give the game props for its visuals, though as stunning as some of them are there are still a few small errors where one resource doesn't quite look like it matches with the rest of the objects of the map (unfortunately a few of the tiles they used from the Futuristic tile pack looked like this for me, but I'm not sure if it's because I know those tiles or because they actually do have a completely different look from the drawn looking resources made for this game)There are other reviews that summarize the story so I'm not going to get too into deconstructing that, but I do have quite a few issues with how things are setup and certain writing through out. Many of the characters (including sadly enough some major characters) come off as very flat in the writing. I also noticed a few minor grammar errors (unfortunately I forgot to note them down since I usually play games through Stream to unwind) but it wasn't anything that really detracted from the intended meaning and took maybe a second longer to process. I do typically like stories and games that try to look or deconstruct moralistic views, but this many times felt a bit like some kind of agenda was being pushed and instead of feeling (as a player) free to pick whatever path I wanted; it seems very clear a lot of times that there's still a very right or wrong option.  Because of this, I don't quite feel like it achieves precisely the level of control over ethics and consequence that the game devs pitched (or maybe I'm just looking at it wrong)Really, one of my major issues and a problem with the game that I don't like at all is it suffers from making a lot of maps just way to big, or at least it feels that way due to not being able to run on some of them (heck, even on the outdoor maps where you are able to run they just feel way to big sometimes; especially since most of the time to get the story you'll probably only go into about half of the buildings available making the rest just extremely large pieces that take up space)Actually, overall it suffers from the wrong kind of padding; as mentioned before the maps are a bit too big occasionally meaning you'll be walking over them many times and many of the actual gameplay elements are either RNG to the point of being annoying or just monotonous actions and possibly prompts. Removing or changing these to a more understandable setup for to the player might have been better, except the game wouldn't have been near as long (I'm up to about 5 hours [that's the total on the save file] right now; that's just for one play through and I haven't even actually reached the ending yet) or probably have as much gameplay.   Also, as nice as it is that the game has its own music, the tracks all get rather annoying pretty quickly; it's pretty unfortunate that there's no way to just turn off the music after awhile.None of this is to turn others off from playing, though; clearly even though it does have these problems there are still quite a number of people who absolutely enjoy what the game devs managed to create with this game and it's still quite possible that you could, too. It just happened to not be a game I enjoyed and that's perfectly okay.

Posted: January 2, 2015
												Always Sometimes Monsters definitely the best Newgrounds-esque game I've played (insofar as it is RPG Maker, but with more effort than most games of that type).  And it's precisely the type of game that makes me wish there were more options than a thumbs up or thumbs down.  The game isn't bad.  Like I said, for the tech level the devs were working with, I'm actually very impressed.  But the dialogue and the writing is so damned pretentious and unrealistic that I found myself rolling my eyes at every second sentence.  It honestly felt like reading something a 16 year old would write after taking his first course in philosophy.  And for a game that puts so much on its story, that's bad.  It's really bad.As for the game itself, why would I want to play a story where the character has a less interesting life than I do?  As soon as I found myself homeless and working odd jobs for money, I needed the story to keep me in the game.  And as I mentioned, the story is too full of itself to carry the experience for me.  I'm a fan of indie games, and I really wanted to like this one, but I couldn't bring myself to give it a really fair chance.I can't recommend the game, but if it's the type of story you're into, and you can stomach the writing, there's something there.

Posted: January 6, 2015
												Here is a good system to determine if you should get this game:1. Have you played To the Moon? If yes, go to 3. If no, go to 2,2. Play To the Moon, go to 33. Did you like To the Moon? If yes, go to 4. If no, go to 6.4. Are you a masochist who would genuinely enjoy a depressing and hopeless story that makes you feel lower than the dirt in the gutter that you step over on your way to work every day? If yes, go to 5. If no, go to 6.5. Play this game...and enjoy being miserable.6. Liberate tuteme ex inferis. (Save yourself from hell)Imagine, if you will, if To the Moon and Tell Tale's the Walking Dead had a baby...and then both parents immediately died after the birth to leave the child in the care of Spec Ops: The Line. That child would grow up to become Always Sometimes Monster.tl;dr - the above is all you need as far as a recommendation is concernedIm seriously on the fence about whether to truly recommend this game. On one hand, it is well written and has a genuinely engaging story. On the other, it makes me want to shove glass under my fingernails as penance for ruining everybody's lives.Youll notice I mentioned To the Moon a lot and for good reason: this game feels like it came from the same developer. Its an 8-bit retro game thats pretty much a serving plate for a really good story (To the Moon was infinitely better, though). You dont sit down to enjoy the plate; the plate is just the method of delivering the food (aka the story). And boy does this food taste like depressing sadness cooked in a fine horrible-people wine...*spoilers* *spoilers* *spoilers* *spoilers* ...and rants belowDont say I didnt warn you. 2 final thoughts/rants (on the story):This game presents itself as a decision based game...its a dirty liar. All of the story elements happen irrespective to your decisions, and in more than one situation I actually had my decisions hyped up as being super important and then the game pretended like the decision never happened. One particular moment stands out:Youre offered to either spend 3 days hunting down 3 car parts through tedious side-quests to fix up a car and win a race...or spend one afternoon to cut the opponent dude's brake line and have him burst into flames literally right in front of his 4 little children (I was in a hurry, dont judge me...though it was hilarious after the fact). The next day, the guy who put you in the situation in the first place, set up the race, a true blue Christian from head to toe, is a pastor at the church, and LITERALLY just presided over the dead dude's funeral with his little children crying "DADDY NOOO" goes up to you and acts like nothing happened and is like "Hey! Ready for that car trip Whatsyourface?" in the most cheery way possible. The decision is only mentioned once more in one of the game's many random pointless questionnaires that means absolutely nothing about whether you regret your decision. Consequences? In a game based entirely around consequences?! Pfft, pass...Lastly, the ending was a huge ****slap. Basically, there is no happy ending; dont even try, youll just screw things up even more. There is literally nothing you can do to get back together with your love interest. Dont believe me? Do some Googlefu and you will.Since Steam forces you to give a yes/no recommendation, I chose my opinion because I am a little happy I played this. Beware, though...this game is definitely not for everyone.

												The one thing this game has going for it is that you can tell it was a labor of love.  It feels very personal, as if the developers created it without the intention of showing it to anyone else, and there's something charming about that.Unfortunately, the awkward writing, the nonsensical plot, and especially the really tedious gameplay (culminating in having to gamble up to a ridiculous amount of money to get the best ending) are too much. Posted: December 27, 2014
												Surprisingly catchy!I got this game out of a humble bundle, and I started playing it without ever looking at the store page. It is very confusing, because it is unlike most of the other games you can find on the market.This is a game about life. Somewhat like The Sims, but this isn't about building a stable life, but rather about surviving a difficult life for a month, and try to get back the love of your life. Also much darker than the sims.At first it will be boring and annoying, just like life. You need money to live, you need to work to get money, and nobody likes to work. But in the middle of these boring, work-filled days, you will be faced with several defining choices... And the next thing you know, you finished the game, and you feel like you just finished watching a really good movie or reading a really good book. And even though it is only a bunch of pixels, and not even particularly realistic, you will feel guilty for behaving like a real monster.

Posted: December 23, 2014
												My overall opinion: A pretty good game, it won't be liked by some people but I gotta say the story and the choices you make/say really did feel like a real choice and the ending wasn't set in stone and there are quite a few ways your journey may end earlier or differently(WARNING! THERE ARE SOME HINTED SPOILERS!)(This Is Just My Own Personal Opinion And How I Felt The Game Was To Me And You Might Feel Different To My Point Of View So Please Be Nice Kay? =)It wasn't a game where you can just get the best ending by just rushing to the end and picking the right dialog, it was focused on choices and life decisions that can cause your own story to end suddenly by taking the wrong turn in life. There are some flaws that I felt made the game feel annoying at some points like the boxing minigame or earning enough income in a short time open up another dialog option later in the story but without knowing all this beforehand you'll be left with just one thing, your own personal choice. (and this is without being a cheat and reading a how-to guide!)The epilogue felt open ended and you cannot revisit the previous town/cities to check up on how they are all doing and your main love interest (if you choose to persue it) simply locks him/herself in a room and you end up having a limit set of options you could do.I truely wished there was abit more to the story in the epilogue, I kinda felt cheated after going through everything just to have my main love interest lock him/herself in so I cannot see or talk to him/her and having it end just like that because I felt there could be abit more story between the main character and the love interest rather than relying mostly on flashback/dreams and maybe having them go together to revisit the town/cities the main character have gone to and see where it goes from there.Heres hoping for dlc or a sequel! but I doubt they'd do that, happens too often~ =P Anyways, this is a good game in which I will play again to see what else it has to offer and the main theme of the game is probably the choice in life and maybe something else =P , I hope you enjoy it if you do buy the game, its total recommended game to get!

Posted: December 23, 2014
												Probably one of the best games I've ever played. I enjoyed every bit of the game, truly, but here are the key parts.The first thing that I instantly noticed was how well the introduction was created. The first scene was a little bit bewildering and confusing since I had no idea what was happening. The first scene took only like three minutes, and that's when the magic began. The way the character and the lover were chosen and introduced was clever. Whereas most games have the character creation not really tied to the story or it's just there at the beginning related to nothing *looks at the Elder Scrolls IV* the character creation really made you feel like a part of the story right off the bat. One of my favourite bits was that you can choose anyone to be your character and you can choose anyone to be the significant others, and whom you choose doesn't have a whole bunch of effects. Sure, there might be a few gay innuendos from the friendly neighbour or some racist butt faces being racist against you and your *black friend (his boss)*, but there isn't anyone saying it's wrong.Because that's not what this game is about.As the developers have stated, the game doesn't care. It doesn't care if you decide to sell the dog to be a police dog, a fight pit dog, or return it back to the owner. The charm about this game is that it's not up to the game to make you content with what you do. There isn't anybody patting you on the back for doing the right thing (something that doesn't exist in this game, as you'll see) or someone telling you that you're a screw up if you do the evil thing (also doesn't really exist), it's practically only you who will be the judge of you. If you feel like you did the wrong thing, then you did the wrong thing. The game doesn't care, and it most likely won't impact you. If you feel like you did the right thing, then you did the right thing. Again, the game doesn't care.What really makes this game great is what I said before: it's special to you because you make it special. It's just you doing the things in the game, with very little forced upon you. You can take that screwdriver and pawn it off simply because you're short on cash. Whoever owned the screwdriver might be mad, but you don't see it, it doesn't effect you negatively. You benefit, he loses. Or you might decide to not accept the bribe. You lose some, others gain some. It's take or pull, but it's what you make of it. Have fun.

Posted: November 16, 2014
												Always Sometimes Monsters is a game where you live the life of a broken adult, trying to reclaim their life but face many decisions that a normal human being would most likely never face. This is the story of your character, whom ever it may be, facing many everyday problems, from money to love. It is an amazing game that always managed to throw my emotions around and made me feel for the character. The one thing I would complain about this game is how the game handles money. Every "main quest" has some cash output for you to progress, but these "main quests" do not give enough money. After you are done with these "main quests", you are stuck to do an odd job at a employment agency to get the remaining cash to progress and these jobs are very tedious and boring, unlike the rest of the game. I would recommend this game to anyone willing to dish out 10 dollars and ~7-8 of their life for an amazing story and never ending music that WILL get stuck in your head.

Posted: July 24, 2014
												My girl left me, my publisher fired me, I'm broke, AND THE PROM IS TOMORROW!On a more serious note, this is a great game that got me geniunely involved with the characters. Most games make you abundently clear that the characters are just that- characters. But in Always Sometimes monsters, I really felt like they were real people, with real consequences for my actions. This isn't a game for everyone, but for someone who likes adventures, a smidge of romance, and grey-and-grey moral choices that could end in disaster or in triumph, this is a shining example of what an RPG should look like. My only qualm was that it wasn't long enough.

Posted: November 20, 2015
												Unlike most RPG's ASM takes place in the real world, dealing with more 'mundane' real world issues in more conventional ways. Instead of a story interspersed with combat sequences your main concern is simply gaining enough money to progress the storyline, paying off rent, getting money for a bus ticket, and things like that. Naturally the way to gain money is through work, and completing odd jobs throughout the game becomes its homologue to combat sequences and grinding found in other RPG's. Unfortunately the job aspect of this game is extremely tedious, although it doesn't take up a huge amount of the game seeing as it's the primary way to earn money I would've liked this process to be a bit more enjoyable. Luckily the work minigames are the only real portion of the game that disappoints. The story is refreshingly original, and tackles a lot of real world issues that were competently handled with a surprising amount of choice and consequence found in the games decisions, which can lead to several different endings. Morality is great here as well, with most of your choices leaning on the gray side of the morality scale.  The characters were well done but sadly the game is short,  so you don't get enough time to really care for the characters except for perhaps the protagonist.  I also enjoyed the soundtrack, which was better than what I expected for an RPG Maker game. The same can't be said for the graphics though, it IS an RPG Maker game after all, and it shows. Overall I'd definitely recommend this game for any RPG fan looking for an unconventional take on the genre, it's not perfect, and it leans on the short side (although it does boast a fair amount of replay value). What it does provide however is an interesting story that tackles tough real world issues with equally tough choices that actually matter, and that's a formula that inevitable leads to a great RPG.

Posted: December 31, 2015
												I want to give this a thumbs down because of how much of an emotional wreck I am right now, but I don't really want to not recommend a game just because of the negative emotion it gave me. For those who have finished this game would understand me, that is, if everything ended sucky for them as well.**MIGHT spoil the game, but I am trying to avoid any spoilers**This game was pretty great, I'm just quite an emotional person and feels always get to me right away. I mean, this game makes me think, we don't easily forget the people that make life worth living, do we?I mean, my character in this game has done so much and in the end, he just gets thrown around like an animal and gets his heart completely crushed. Too much effort, just for that to happen... Does a legacy of effort mean anything in this world anymore?If I had a happy ending, that would be Sam standing there and I would be the cause of HIS/HER unhappy ending. Maybe Sam's been as miserable as me. Maybe he/she doesn't deserve an unhappy ending...but it's either me or the other person who gets that happiness; there always has to be one person who has to be the miserable one. Should I accept my fate and stay silent?No matter what choice we make in this world...there are always sometimes monsters.__Okay, so enough of that crap. There were some things in this game that I could definitely see me doing / see happen to me in the future so I got really into it. I thought this game was totally worth it ESPECIALLY if it's on sale. There's romance, a lot of comedy, oh, and a hecka lot of quotes I wish I wrote down (I may or may not have used some above). I'd definitely recommend this to people who like romance and comedy - and people who like feels.I would write a PROS list, but my opinion about what I like doesn't really matter. Different people like different things. BUT I am going to write a CON list because sometimes we gotta look at the bad before caring too much about the good.Cons:-Sometimes the objectives in this game isn't as specific as the others (might get lost/confused about what you're supposed to do next) but you'll get back in track after a few minutes of wandering.-There were times where this game was boring *cough* Tofu job *cough* but it added to the steadiness of the game (rather than having too much stuff like maybe uh uhm yeah the ending bye)-Choices that leave you thinking after a while-If you're SUPER emotional and a sissy like me, you'd be feeling uncomfortable and broken-CHARACTERS THAT MAKE YOU WANT TO BREAK THINGS-Sam -why does the kid only want to fish for crabs?? are people going to notice the floating corpse?? and HOW ABOUT THAT SMASHED WINDOW?!-i need money and food-some of the music made my eyes twitch (sorry)-Most of the guys did not look attractive. Only the females looked nice (most of the time)Pros:(I said I wouldn't, but I want to write just a FEW things)-The game is steady, not too much going on.-Dream scenes - oh my god I love it when games have these-The game lasted longer than I thought it would (I would always be anxious to play but I was too scared to finish it)[there are a lot more probs, I am just too upset to focus on the good things right now]__Well, I hope you guys enjoy this game, if you do buy it. Maybe gift your friend the game as well and then compare choices. And I hope someone would list all the quotes in this game and put them on wiki/imdb or some website or something. All the quotes in this game are magnificent. The deep quotes always get to me oh my god. Anyways, enjoyt the game. And thanks to the people who read through all my nonsense.

Posted: July 10, 2016
												This is the first ever RPGMaker game that I have played through to completion.The game hooked me with the initial setup. I'm a sucker for any plot that starts out with a mysterious masked gunman, and a standoff situation that makes you want to know what the ♥♥♥♥ is going on.That is something that, IMHO, this game did well.There is not much in the way of gameplay challenge here, though you can get a game over by making certain choices.As an adventure game, there is not much that will leave you scratching your head - it's pretty easy to wander around and find something to move the plot along. Though there are however a few little secrets to find.The biggest strength of this game is its story, a somewhat mundane story about lost love, redemption, self-improvement and such. I found it good enough to keep me playing.The second selling point is the morality choices, which in general play out and have consequences that make you feel like you actually made a choice, and weren't just railroaded.So I would recommend this game if you don't mind pixel graphics, you're interested in a mellower plot than most games provide, and you are looking for some 'choice porn' to tide you over in between the next big open-world-action-rpg outing.Also, you get to work in a meat packing plant at one point, and there is a 'press enter to masturbate' scene, so there's that too.

Posted: June 10, 2016
												Summary: "Always Sometimes Monsters" is a story-only RPG. There's no combat, no skill systems, no hidden item search, and the puzzles are for the most part optional. The story is about a young, penniless writer. It begins with the main character being evicted from their apartment, and on the same day receiving a wedding invitation to their ex-boy/girlfriend's wedding in one month's time. They set out to bus and hitchhike across the country to the wedding within 30 days.For me it was kind of a mixed bag. I tentatively recommend it, mainly because I just love this genre of game. Most of the gameplay consists of exploring the three towns the main character visits, getting involved in characters and conflicts, and making choices to help or hurt them. The game contains a pretty large set of things to discover and choices to make, and I loved that.Also, you can choose your avatar and their boy/girlfriend from a range of men and women of different races. You can play as a man or a woman, gay or straight. That didn't matter much to me, but I'm sure it's a selling point for some folks out there.The main downside to this mixed bag, is that the game drags. You move at a walking pace around the map, with no option to run (none that I found anyway). You can't skip cutscenes, only individual lines of dialog. And you pretty much have to spend a decent amount of time on boring temp jobs to earn the bus money needed to get to the end of the game. This wouldn't be a huge problem if you were set on treating this like real life and just playing through it one time, accepting the unforeseen outcome of every choice and mistake. But with so many choices and mutually exclusive paths through the game, it implicitly invites you to play it again to see what would have happened if you'd chosen differently, or even just to back up to a save point if it turns out that a line of dialogue you picked means something different than you thought it did.Even before I got into the game proper, I had to rewind through two excruciatingly slow scenes. The game is told as a flashback, so it opens with a scene from the frame story, and partway through that you have the choice to make the POV character shoot the character who's going to have the flashback. If you choose that (and of course I did to see what would happen), you get an early "Game Over" and have to restart from the beginning of this non-skippable cut scene. This is immediately followed by a scene at a party where the POV character chooses who to have a drink with, which turns out to be how you pick your avatar. If you don't realize this before you make the choice (as I didn't) you later get a chance to return to the start of the scene, which I did, forcing me through another annoying repetition.Another minor annoyance is the game's level of preachiness. It's like one of those moralistic anime series where the main characters are warm-hearted and human but most people in society are completely depraved selfish monsters. This wasn't a deal-breaker for me; I just kind of took it with a grain of salt, as part of the fictional world the game is set in. But it would have been nice if some of the moral choices you were making were more two-sided, instead of clearly always having a "good" side and a "bad" side. Indeed, to get the happiest ending at the end of the game you have to, at one point, say that you are unqualifiedly sorry for every single thing you did that transgressed the normal rules of society, even if you were doing it to save someone's life. It's like Kant's categorical imperative up in here.And then there's that ungrammatical title. I guess it's supposed to mean "All people can sometimes be monstrous". But the awkward self-contradiction of "Always Sometimes" just irks me a little every time I see it. At least the game itself pokes some fun at this, with a character in-game seeing it as the title of a book and puzzling over what the heck it means.Lol, so now I've written a lot of details about what was bad about the game, but I'm still going to recommend it. If you like RPGs based on exploration and character interaction rather than combat, you'll probably enjoy this game. At least, the first time through. If you're patient.

Posted: June 13, 2016
												I don't like ragging on games too much, but I believe this is an extremely poor game. It's way too late to write a review to warn people against buying it, but I can at least make the case for those who will look at it in the future. The gameplay is bad, because of a number of design choices:The use of large areas that inflate the game time by forcing you to walk back and forth through them, that become increasingly empty and devioid of meaningful interactions the further you go into the game (said large areas are also often bland and anonymous, the art isn't much better than what you could expect from the standard RPGMaker tilesets, althogh the palette fits the mood and the urban environment are reasonably portrayed);Game mechanics that are more suited for point and click adventures. perhaps visual novels or time-management games, that weren't correctly translated into a game using the RPG Maker engine. Often, you waste insane amounts of time conferming your actions/choices over and over again, the dialogue that is the meat of this game is served in minimal tidbits, the choices suffer similar restrictions, the "fatigue" mechanic is poorly implemented, since you just need to have some of it right before you go to bed, opening it to being exploited, the money-making is easily exploitable too, especially if one wants to save-scum (there really isn't a need for it, for the most part, although you might be screwed if you go to a new area without some starting money or at least food and you don't want to exploit the game);A huge amount of choices you make seem to matter very little, you briefly encounter people and then you don't interact with them ever again, or just get a few lines near the ending. Considering most of the gameplay is bad mini-games, poor resource management mechanics AND choices, you'd expect at least this one to be explored in-depth, but you'd be wrong.The writing is also bad, which is particularly jarring in such a narrative-focused game. The plot is set on having you go at your ex's wedding at all costs (that's the entire push behind the entire plot, that sees you struggle with your financial situation to try and get together enough money to get there and survive), but at the same time the story lets you re-affirm everytime that you are over him/her. The ending you get if you are consistent with this behavior makes no sense, though, as you are seemingly destroyed by the fact that things go just as planned.The ending is the least of the game's problems, though, and in fact it at least embraces the theme that permeates the game about circumstances dictating a lot of what our choices actually are, the problem is that the writing is bad through the entire experience, and the ending couldn't possibly escape from that. The plot is a string of contrivances usually solved by deus-ex-machina or similar, obvious narrative devices. For a game that goes for a serious approach, and could be classified as a drama, having such unbeliavable/stupid plot points severely undermines the struggles of the protagonist, making the whole even less believable. I found the comedy in the game to be frankly terrible, but I am going to concede this might be subjective, I do think that regardless of that, it further clashes with the themes, taking the believability of the drama further down, as it pops-up whenever it damn well pleases it. The presence of the game's authors in the game itself is just icing on the cake, beating you over the head with commentary on the themes in the story (which you could argue are flatly stated early on anyway). I can say, without kidding, that I have played porn games made in RPGMaker and similar engines, that have more nuanced and interesting writing than this. I believe you need incredibly low standards to be okay with it, especially since you can't rely on the gameplay to entertain you.The music didn't have particularly catchy or emotional tunes, I don't think it's terrible, but it's extremely forgettable.I will conclude by saying that I can only assume this game wasn't created to tell a story that also had a message, but instead it was written because they wanted to express a message, and reverse-engineered a story to suit said message. The characters are there to serve one function and little else, and I honestly regret spending my life playing this game. I checked 3-4 endings, although there might be slight variations to each and even some I didn't see, but the staggering amount of repeated dialogues even in these put me off from trying another playthrough, so after seeing the ones I could easily get by reloading a previous save file, I am more than done with this.

Posted: March 23, 2016
												Always Sometimes Monsters is a unique game that I quite enjoyed. There were a few things that could have been improved, but overall, I liked it. I will try my best to describe my experience that will hopefully influence your decision to buy or not.When I first launched the game, I was intrigued by the graphic style. Please note that the graphics were one of the reasons why I purchased the game since they reminded me a bit of MySim games. I had a lot of trouble initally with the controls. Nowhere in the main menu did they give you instructions of how to control the game. I could have looked it up on the Internet (which I did after ten minutes), but my first reaction was to randomly click around on my keyboard until I figured out everything I could do. But unfortually, I hit F12, which reset my game and I had to redo the first ten minutes I played over. At least I wasn't hours into it. After I realized I could plug my Xbox remote into my PC and use the controller to play, I have used that instead of the keyboard since.The game became addicting. I played hours on end, but tried to cut my time short of only playing 2-3 hours a day. Again, there was something that I had trouble with, and I had to do a little searching online. As the days progressed in-game, I wasn't sure what to do. I think that the developers could have put in a mechinism where, if the player is stuck, we could go to a spot in a menu to find a goal or something to figure out what to do. You'll notice (if you play) that there are times where you need to waste time in the day without a set goal in mind. That's where things get repeatative.As your chosen character, you want to get to San Vernadino (I might've spelt it wrong, sorry), but if you made mistakes along the way (again, you'll know what I mean if you play), you'll need to make money to buy bus tickets to get there. Luckily, in almost every town, there is a building where you go to find a job to work for the morning, afternoon, or evening. To get the certain amount needed, this process is repeated over and over again, and becomes tiresome. I can understand why some players quit at that point, but I say try not to. It feels quite rewarding when you finally have enough money to get to the next town.I've found that certain mini-games within the game are difficult. When you go to Salt City, you have to play a boxing mini-game if you don't want to go through with an alternative method. It was very difficult because I spent over an hour just on this because the mechanics were hard to figure out. When you reach this part, I'd suggest searching in the Always Sometimes Monsters discussions on Steam. Just search "boxing game", and there should be a post that will give you descriptive advice on how to beat it.Lastly, I want to talk about the ending. It left me kind of missing something. I don't know what other choices I could have made in the past that would have improved it, but I worried that choosing certain things in the last few minutes wouldn't have made a difference. I don't know for sure if this game has "replay value" or not because of the mini-games, but I'll find out. I definitely want to see if any other choices will change if I replay the game.So far, I have enjoyed this game a lot. Like I said, it reminds me of MySims, so it's kind of nostalgic since I played that game as a kid. This is the grown up version of MySims. It's addicting, enjoyable, and rewarding. Oh, and a quick tip for those of you who will decide to play: Save your game often. Don't save it on the "auto" save file, but on one of the other ones. That way, you can reload if you think you messed up. If you aren't sure of when to save, just save your game if you think something big will happen, or before you enter a building you were told to enter.7.5/10.

Posted: March 28, 2016
												Even if it's flawed, Always Sometimes Monsters managed to interest me for the whole playthrough and I happily recommend it to anybody who likes adventures with an emphasis on character development and non-linear storylines. The most relevant comparison which comes to mind is with To The Moon: if you liked it, you will probably at least appreciate what ASM has to offer. With respect to To The Moon, this one is in a sense a more ambitious game: it deals with (not always perfectly) many mature themes (it actually goes where few games dare to), but it also presents you with a much more complex storyline and a basic free-roaming structure with lots of options and different outcomes.This non-linear nature really shines not only during the very first moments, when you are given a lot of freedom in choosing your character, but also when you feel that the game actually responds to your choices. I went for a female protagonist and I could really identify myself with her pursuit of success, freedom and, most of all, lost love.Many different outcomes are possible, but I have to say that the one I got didn't entirely do justice to my personal path, as I probably expected something more connected to my choices during the game and to the character I created inside my head. This is of course a problem for any game which presents such a non-linear and relatively complex structure; moreover I grew fond of my character and her personal growth, so probably my expectations were pretty difficult to be met.So, even if it sometimes falls short of its premise, Always Sometimes Monsters is an original and occasionally touching experience, with a very nice and recognizable soundtrack and lots of references and easter eggs.7.5/10

Posted: May 6, 2015
												There is a difference between a sad story and a depressing story.After a sad story we feel catharsis. We feel like we've explored an idea, like we've walked in another person's shoes. Sure, the story didn't turn out well, but not everything in life does. We can learn from it. Sad stories serve a purpose.A depressing story, on the other hand, tells us nothing we don't already know. Life sucks. Work is boring and unfulfilling. Society is cruel and unfair. Damn near nobody cares about us; they're all out to get their own. Connections we make in our lives are all the more precious for being freaking rare, and we have to treasure the few good things we have for the limited time we still have them. We know all that.After experiencing a sad story, you feel cleansed. After experiencing a depressing story, you want 1.4 hours of your life back.Judging by my rating, in which category do you think I place this ridiculous runaround of a game?I guess someone who's had a much easier life than mine might find a game like this eye-opening. Honestly, though, it's so far removed from reality anyway that it can't even be instructive.

Posted: May 6, 2015
												Spoilers Included:Majors in a story-telling aspect with allusion to some of your choices actually mattering with some interesting social commentary. Loses it’s steam due to tedious repetitive segments complete with poor pacing, obvious plot twists, and revolving around mostly nothing but your grinding/luck with money.What’s interesting is it actually gives away it’s concept pretty early while talking to the meta in-game developers as “Would you be interested in playing a game where you’re not the hero” and the game tries to accomplish just that. You stem into this journey in attempt to see your partner betrothed at someone else’s hand and the cost of doing such may cost you your own morality and people will question that as time passes but in the end it just comes to this giant “meh” of a selective ending unless you really want♥♥♥♥♥♥to warp into the soap opera zone.The characters 8/10 of the times are cynical ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s, their attempt to get you connected to your partner completely revolves around these short flashbacks you get every maybe 30% of game completion with very little substance whatsoever and devalues the plot by about 50%, it’s an attempt to give you a visual novel experience by Devolver Digital standards (surprise, surprise) and just barely manages to withhold it’s own without coming off as pointless.

The graphics and character abilities are extremely limited, but that is not the selling point of this game.  It seems the author/game creators wanted to make an interactive romance novel.

Posted: May 3, 2015
												It's an RPG Maker game so you already know it offers the most basic of gameplay in an .exe that hopefully works without having to change some properties. Can't say anything new about that or recommend it to people who are tired with those types of Verge RPG programs from way back. The main draw for this one is its choose-your-own-adventure story system. Unfortunately, that means it had better be written well to be worth $10. Same goes for the $5 soundtrack, which is also too boring and uninspiring to be worth it.Gamers have a very low bar for what’s considered good writing, it seems. No achievement for shooting that first long-winded bum who kept prattling on about choice? C’mon, we were supposed to not hate that dialogue? The biggest problem with moral dilemma stories written by gamers is that it’s so obvious what the intended choice is. They all think the same. Besides, when you have the choice between “Well, I guess you’re right if you really think about it” and “Get the ♥♥♥♥ out of here, I’m not an awful person ugh,” it’s not hard to figure out which path the writer’s hoping you choose, especially since there’s always a trigger involved. Sex? Kinda sketchy. Drugs? Tools of the devil. Old people? Gotta respect ‘em. Do I steal the game dev’s money or do I leave it alone? I wonder which one results in the Game Over.“It’s supposed to make you mad/sad so you could think about the other choices you could’ve made/consequences of your actions! That’s what we set out to do. We’re artists.” Ok.I’m happy to see modern-day RPG Maker stuff, I really am, and I’m impressed that the team was able to make money off of it but they might wanna grab someone from the NaNoWriMo forums who’s desperate to get their grand works out there next time. Who knows, the gimmick might work. “Budding novelist hopeful teams up with indie vidya designer for passion project. Adam Sessler rises from the grave to promote it until it’s written about in Time Magazine. The medium is finally transcending!” It’s not like anyone’s expecting Walden Simulator or A Sport and a Pastime: The Game.Or, you know, you can just ramble about fate or cry about your ex-girlfriend some more.12/10 would whine about binary moral decisions again.
