Posted: January 19, 2015
												I really wanted to like this game; I forced myself to play for almost 15 hours of it and just can’t bring myself into playing anymore. For a story driven game it has shockingly bad writing. The game is about the struggles we face in everyday life, yet the story was completely detached from reality. I mean, there are actions can potently lead to the deaths of multiple people without any repercussions, even though you *spoiler alert* wrote it into a journal which you published into a book!And you know the scene in the dark alley at the start? That’s what got me to keep playing because I wanted to see how the rest of the game tied in to it. Guess what? It doesn’t. Those characters showed up at the very end, and are completely shoed in to justify the first scene.The writing is also extremely pretentious. It spends too much time talking about philosophy of right and wrong, rather than showing through their action of its character. Which is a wasted opportunity, as many characters has potential for development (like Mark). The saying “show, don’t tell” really applies here.The gameplay is pretty much non- existence. Which is fine in “To the Moon” (another story-driven rpg-maker game), because it’s short and to the point. While in this game, I spend 15 hours in this game and still haven’t finished it (I watched a let’s play if you are wondering how I know the ending). It is drawn out and tedious, which would have been okay if the story was good, but it wasn’t.All this would have been forgivable if the developers weren’t so ♥♥♥♥ing pleased with themselves. It’s okay to be proud of your work; it’s also okay put yourself in the game as a character.  What isn’t okay is *spoiler alert* to have a book in the game called “Always Sometimes Monsters” and calling it a masterpiece, and saying that “nothing captures the human spirit quite so well” which it clearly doesn’t, and of yourself show up to offer the author  1 million dollars to turn it into a game.With all that said I hope they learn their lesson and make a better game next time, games like this are few and far between.

Posted: January 14, 2015
												Its a choose your own adventure game threaded  together using ALOT of boring minigames. being able to choose how you want to deal with situations presented in the game is the best part, but sometimes I saw my choices didn't save (ie. Someone died, they're alive later). The story was an interesting idea, most of the conversations with characters were pretty great and well written, however some conversations and story points made me go wtf, didn't make sense, or was just badly thought out and written. I like the changing settings and how there were at least 3 full towns to explore, however lacking towards the end in SV. Now as a choose your adventure/choice game I would recommend it hesitantly.BUT absolute worst thing this game does is create a very long amount of trash filler minigames to tie the story together.From my playthrough I played 3 arcade minigames (one pacman ripoff), 2 job minigames (Tofu/Weed jobs), coat check minigame, box minigame, hacking minigame (frogger ripoff), vent maze, deliver drugs minigame, boxing minigame, 4 casino minigames. I hated them. Almost all the minigames I listed are required for progress or jobs done to progress the day. By the end of the game, I've had enough and didn't even play any of the casino minigames cause that's a stupid idea. I hated those boring minigame segments that are half the game.Also, the developer cameo was great at first in the coffee shop, but wtf was with the two of them, and that ending at the book store was so stupidly bad I laughed.Do not recommend.

Posted: January 21, 2015
												This is just awesome. One of the best videogames, storywise especially, i ever played. The fact, that you're roleplaying yourself and are able to weave you're own life (and SO) into this, makes it so relatable. But moreover, the dialogues and characters, the relationships and up's and down's of everyone seem so authentic and just realistic. Of course, there are some "deus ex machina"-like nudges for the sake of being a videogame. But this doesn't hurt. In fact, this game perfectly captures the balance between story, openness while still being a game at heart. The artstyle is a bit grim but mostly simple, yet realistic and authentic. Music is very nice and fits the themes of the cities.Gonna make more playthroughs, there were just so many interesting decisions and choices. All in all this might be the most realistic or authentic videogame i've ever played.Many props to the creators, and thank you sooo much for not only giving the players same-sex options but also for avoiding stereotypes and making a gay relationship natural while playing the game. I really found many relations to my own relationship. Exceptionally well executed.

Posted: March 23, 2016
												Always Sometimes Monsters is a unique game that I quite enjoyed. There were a few things that could have been improved, but overall, I liked it. I will try my best to describe my experience that will hopefully influence your decision to buy or not.When I first launched the game, I was intrigued by the graphic style. Please note that the graphics were one of the reasons why I purchased the game since they reminded me a bit of MySim games. I had a lot of trouble initally with the controls. Nowhere in the main menu did they give you instructions of how to control the game. I could have looked it up on the Internet (which I did after ten minutes), but my first reaction was to randomly click around on my keyboard until I figured out everything I could do. But unfortually, I hit F12, which reset my game and I had to redo the first ten minutes I played over. At least I wasn't hours into it. After I realized I could plug my Xbox remote into my PC and use the controller to play, I have used that instead of the keyboard since.The game became addicting. I played hours on end, but tried to cut my time short of only playing 2-3 hours a day. Again, there was something that I had trouble with, and I had to do a little searching online. As the days progressed in-game, I wasn't sure what to do. I think that the developers could have put in a mechinism where, if the player is stuck, we could go to a spot in a menu to find a goal or something to figure out what to do. You'll notice (if you play) that there are times where you need to waste time in the day without a set goal in mind. That's where things get repeatative.As your chosen character, you want to get to San Vernadino (I might've spelt it wrong, sorry), but if you made mistakes along the way (again, you'll know what I mean if you play), you'll need to make money to buy bus tickets to get there. Luckily, in almost every town, there is a building where you go to find a job to work for the morning, afternoon, or evening. To get the certain amount needed, this process is repeated over and over again, and becomes tiresome. I can understand why some players quit at that point, but I say try not to. It feels quite rewarding when you finally have enough money to get to the next town.I've found that certain mini-games within the game are difficult. When you go to Salt City, you have to play a boxing mini-game if you don't want to go through with an alternative method. It was very difficult because I spent over an hour just on this because the mechanics were hard to figure out. When you reach this part, I'd suggest searching in the Always Sometimes Monsters discussions on Steam. Just search "boxing game", and there should be a post that will give you descriptive advice on how to beat it.Lastly, I want to talk about the ending. It left me kind of missing something. I don't know what other choices I could have made in the past that would have improved it, but I worried that choosing certain things in the last few minutes wouldn't have made a difference. I don't know for sure if this game has "replay value" or not because of the mini-games, but I'll find out. I definitely want to see if any other choices will change if I replay the game.So far, I have enjoyed this game a lot. Like I said, it reminds me of MySims, so it's kind of nostalgic since I played that game as a kid. This is the grown up version of MySims. It's addicting, enjoyable, and rewarding. Oh, and a quick tip for those of you who will decide to play: Save your game often. Don't save it on the "auto" save file, but on one of the other ones. That way, you can reload if you think you messed up. If you aren't sure of when to save, just save your game if you think something big will happen, or before you enter a building you were told to enter.7.5/10.

content:
Posted: January 6, 2016
												I want to like this game. A RPG in a contemporary setting, that doesn't involve saving the kingdom or mechs (as cool as those are). A RPG that examines the modern condition, its ups and downs, and the choices people always sometimes have to make. In some parts, it can be illuminating and daresay enlightening. The music is unique, each city and town has a subtle feel. The artwork, though not masterclass, is quite good. I almost, almost mind you, forget that I'm playing a game made in RPGMaker. I played it all the way to the end. I got every achievement (though they are checkpoint achievements, so not the greatest accolade). So, I want to like this game, but I don't. I find it interesting, promising, and quite unique. Indeed, this Toronto-born award-laden project makes me proud to be a Canadian gamer.  But at the end of 10+ hours, I am unwilling to recommend this game.For about 50% of the journey, there are interesting twists and turns. Interesting characters, insights, and questions raised. Your choices are, if not at least an illusion, actual choices. Then it comes off the rails in the final chapters. For all the choices made, the detail in people and places, the mood and atmosphere: the story begins to make less and less sense. Given certain paths in the story you choose: the ending can make a lot of sense or no sense. The storyteller's conceit from the top of the game can be brilliant or just downright bizarre. For all the great beginnings, the meat of the story before it: the ending is just a miss. This is not a gamer lamenting a bad ending that he didn't manage to avoid. Even on the "good" ending (or one of them, depending on your point of view), I was just confused. This is a game with a message, trying to tell us something we don't often hear. It is a game trying to do something that isn't a nostalgia trip to bygone JRPGs of yesteryear. Yet, it all falls apart.So, do I recommend this game? No, not to everyone.Do I hate this game? No, I am disappointed.Should they have not made it? Better to fail ambitiously than to succeed in mediocrity.I cannot recommend this game because, I feel, that it missed the execution of the ending. A story with a poorly handled ending is just the death of story-driven tales like ASM. Yet, I cannot bring myself to hate this game. For all the ending had failed; the promise of a great modern-day RPG that stands apart from all rivals: that is well worth trying. I would rather the boys and gals at Vagabond make the attempt and miss; than for no one to ever try. I cannot condemn this game as something that should never have been.  There is too much promise and hope in such a title. Even if you don't get the happiest ending possible (if one could call it that.)This is an interesting game that I hope Vagabond makes a similar attempt at. This is a game that other developers should strive to perfect. This is the sort of game that modern gaming we see more of and not less. So if you want to have a little inspiration, a little glimmer of what a unique game could be like, then buy this;  play it; and make it better. Indeed, keep an eye out for future games by this studio: they have a masterpiece in them: they just have to make it.~~~~~~~This is a Review Based from First Complete Playthrough. I intend to play it again as differently as I can manage to see if there is something hidden; something more that I missed the first time through. I sincerely doubt it; but upon second completion: I will add more here.

content:
Posted: January 6, 2016
												My hour count is high because I left the game running (whoops). For the record, I finished it once, and it didn't take me that long.The whole point of this game is to get back with your ex. Problem is, he's getting married. Winning requires you to tear apart a pretty happy existing relationship. It's a fun game through the middle if you're not expecting it to be too serious. But the main arc of the story and some of the people who are supposed to be main characters are so ridiculously juvenile, it's not even funny. And the ending turns out awful for someone no matter what. I don't mind games with no "happily ever after"--but there should be an option where a core character doesn't end up wishing they were dead.Trigger warnings for suicide-, drug-, and death-related stuff. Crops up a couple times, and although it was kind of hackneyed, it's worth mentioning that if that stuff pushes bad buttons for you, this game isn't worth it. Ending aside, there's this one pretty early on: One minor-ish character commits suicide if you don't pick the right choices when you talk to him. He calls you up, thanks you for your advice, and then shoots himself while on the line with you. He's not the most believable character, but still, if you happen to be playing at night, in a dark room, while sleep-deprived, it's pretty jarring. (I was.)If you're still interested in playing, there's a really good step-by-step guide here that tells you what to do to get the 'good ending' (scare quotes) or in case you get stuck. It doesn't spoil the actual plot just by reading the guide.


Step-By-Step Good Ending Guide 
A Guide for Always Sometimes Monsters
By: Ceaseless Duality

			It's a step-by-step walkthrough to get the player through the game, while also achieving the good ending.		


I used it loosely as I played, so I did get the 'good ending', but had I made my own choices, that wouldn't have happened. By the end I was pretty disgusted with the three main characters--they're all kind of jerks. MC does some questionable stuff over the course of her (or his, it was her for me) adventure, and then chooses to stop a wedding during the ceremony when she could have literally spoken up days before it happened and saved a lot of expense, drama, and effort. Aaaaaarrrgghh. Your ex strings Sam along to the point of almost marrying her when he actually wants you, and then ditches her when you show up and just say that you wuv him and he should stop before he makes a Big Mistake because you two are ~soulmates~. And then Sam--oh, Sam.She invited you to her wedding just to shove it in your face that she was marrying your old flame, and brag about her huge book deal. Either that, or she's an idiot. There's no indication that the main character and Sam kept in touch or were still friends in any way. MC did kind of "steal" her crush (he chose MC over her, if you call that stealing), and MC got a book deal that was supposed to be for both her and Sam but cut Sam out of the deal, and ended up taking it anyway (it was a sticking point).I got really annoyed when Sam got held at gunpoint over her gambling debts and wanted your manuscript so she could cash in on her book deal and pay off her debts--and I mean annoyed at both characters. I was really irritated with Sam, of course, but I was also irritated because where were her friends when she got carted off to play high-stakes cards? Sam has a reputation for getting drunk at parties and wandering off to get into trouble, so why weren't they watching her a little better? Can't someone around here act like a responsible adult? (Preferably Sam, but that was never going to happen.) And then Sam's life is in danger and MC gripes about what giving her the manuscript will do to MC's career. This is the same MC who blackmailed a doctor because "a life is a life"--remember? Anyway, you can pay it off without giving up the book, but it requires major minigame work or gambling or one of a couple other options that are pretty boring.So, either you take your book/crush and become happy and successful and Sam ends up in the gutter, or vice versa, because apparently nothing is more important than Marrying Your Soulmate, and success is a zero-sum game. (eyeroll) What happened to Sam's giant book deal, anyway? How... never mind, I'm going to stop trying to make sense of this.There were parts that were fun, though.In the second town, I ditched both the union job and the protesters and joined the detective instead. He was obviously a Superman reference on legs, really boring, but he didn't stick around long. I got a kick out of the computer scenes. Snork. In case any of you are designing games--they'll tell you in Networking 1 that anyone can get into just about any network machine if they've got physical access to it. There's no need for them to move floppy disks around little fire sprites in a minigame.I really liked Markansas. He was a believable character that you could totally empathize with, and he was a decent guy who just genuinely wanted to help the MC. I appreciated the inclusion of a Christian character not portrayed as a jerk, even if it wasn't 100% accurate and the related writing (his sermon in particular) was really stilted, but they still looked up a real Bible verse relevant to what he was saying. (I should hope that a church service involves more than one verse though. Especially one lasting like four hours or whatever that was.)Also, racial diversity. That was pretty cool--I've only played as the Japanese (?) girl and got a few comments based on my race, but I wonder if people are more distrustful of you if you're a black guy or something? Speaking of which... I, uh, think my character put on blackface to disguise herself while she raided the doctor's mansion for teddy bear bondage porn to use as blackmail material, and I don't know how to feel about that.That may be the weirdest single sentence I've ever written in a game review, so I'm going to leave it there.

Posted: January 18, 2016
												THE SYSTEM REQUIREMENTS LISTED FOR PLAYING THIS GAME ON A MAC ARE NO LONGER ACCURATE. IT REQUIRES 10.9 NOW. WOULDN'T YOU LIKE TO KNOW HOW I FOUND OUT?!?I played this game for nearly 5 hours in total. I want to guess I was halfway through it. (I just got to the trailer park, for those of you that know what that means.) I let my games update automatically and it's never given me trouble before. This game updates, and suddenly, I can no longer play it unless I update my IOS system. Maybe I'd update it, but I literally just updated my IOS system a month ago, and it was such a  pain in the♥♥♥♥♥that doing it again now would feel pretty ludicrous.  Not to mention, if I do end up updating my IOS system and decide to play this, I have to start the game all over again. While this game was interesting in concept, replaying the past 4.8 hours of menial work to buy bus tickets sounds a lot more boring than I want to admit. I really wanted to like this game, I knew it was building up to something, and now I don't get to experience what that something would've been. Luckily I bought this game when it was on sale, but that doesn't take away the dissapointment that after getting invested in my character and the story so much, I don't get to find out how my character's story ends.  Maybe if I got to finish the game, I would have given a good review.

Posted: January 25, 2016
												Did I enjoy it: YesIs it a good game: Debateable, but I'm going to say yesCons can basically all be pointed back to the choice of RPG Maker as the engine. However, if you can look past that you'll find a game that tackles some interesting topics in a novel way.How many games allow you the opportuntiy to be homeless and unemployed? Or face discrimination based on your race, sex or sexuality? Even the minigames in which you make money are an exercise in dealing with boredom - probably an artistic choice on the designer's part, but not a smart mvoe when making a game.All in all, I found it engrossing. It's basically a road-trip movie that takes itself seriously, and wants to explroe the darker side of the modern world. Dialogue can get incredibly preachy and go on too long about simple philosophical concepts, and some people feel they were rail-roaded too much in the latetr part of the game after the initial 'open world' experience of the first act, but these are minor niggles. The fact that most NPCs treat you differently based on race, sex and age are all commendable, showing that these choices matter.Always Sometimes Monsters delivers a good story, has some solid points to make and dares to do something different.

Posted: February 26, 2016
												This was a fun story, I had thought the choices would matter more but I loosely followed one of the guides on here (I was worried about messing up!) and the ending turned out fine. There are, however, a lot of choices you can make, which I liked. I was in a rush to get to the final city, but you can afford to take your time. I wish I had taken a bit more time during my playthrough, but what's done is done. There are times that you have to grind to get cash and skipping that could lessen the game's enjoyablility. They're making a sequel right now and I would totally get it. This game also allows you to not only pick your gender, but the gender of your love interest (and no one bats an eye!). The wiki is horribly incomplete, I had missed some side stuff that is really circumstantial to get to, so it'd be nice if there was more support on that end, but all in all I would definitely get the game if you have nothing else better to do. Note: getting back to the game after a few weeks of not playing was tough, I had completely forgotten the storyline and what I was supposed to do, so jotting down notes after every session would be beneficial if you don't play this in one go (which I don't recommend).

I have and will continue to recommend this game, and will likely replay it again myself.

Posted: March 5, 2016
												The game is story-driven and you have to ignore the fact that RPG Maker is not the best engine, I got it. But I couldn't enjoy the story and the characters whatsoever (just the old lady, the old lady is adorable). The characters are very poorly written. There's a lady who had a problem with drugs and she's supposed to be your friend. But why? I don't know! And you have to make a decision to save her. But I had no sympathy for her at all! And that's how I saw all the characters in this game: all of them are very shallow (including the protagonist). With no sympathy for the main characters, what's left? A monotonous game, full of tedious and repetitive jobs. The soundtrack is also very repetitive. I just don't recommend it.

Posted: March 8, 2016
												Always Sometimes Monsters is a game of tough decisions. I really enjoyed the game play, even if I found it frustrating at times to have to choose between a bad option and a bad option (hi, real life). The final section has a nice part where you have to justify your actions (to your ex's parent), and your gameplay throughout will dictate which ending you get. The opening scene where you get to select your played character and the love interest is nicely done, offering variety in gender and race. It would have been interesting to see gender and race have an impact in how those around you interact, especially given the nature of the game.

Posted: February 9, 2016
												Remember those "choose your own adventure books" you read as a child? This game fills that simple void. It's real, interesting, and you become invested in the character and, like in our own every day lives, question the choices that are made. Are you making the most morally right decision, or the easiest? I bought this game as my first Steam purchase after seeing a good friend play it and attempt to explain it to me, and it piqued my interest greatly - and I don't regret the decision I made. The game is easy, fun, and low-key enough that you can waste a few hours on it when you just want something to loose yourself in without getting too invested. It's a decent purchase and has a lot of re-playability that makes it worth the price.

Posted: July 24, 2016
												Light/medium spoilers ahead!! You've been warned!!!!Probably my favorite game of all time. I can't even pin down what about it I loved SO much, but mostly it was the reality of it. The atmospheres, the settings, were all so familiar. I imagine my life isn't too different from the MC's, because the places she goes and lives are eerily similar to my own. IMO it's very reflective of the USA's atmosphere and everything was incredibly well done in that regard.The sound and soundtrack was phenomenal, albeit maybe a bit repetitive, but it barely got on my nerves at all. The characters were all solid and unique and felt real. Even the background characters all had so much to say. There is so much attention to detail in this game it's crazy.I personally liked the grinding and the stamina aspect, I liked the gambling and fighting a lot. I liked how I could actually play as a gay character that didn't have the gay part glossed over--it was actually brought up multiple times, which I found very impressive and I really enjoyed it.I don't think I can say enough about how much I like this game. I don't think I have anything negative to say about it at all...I do wish that if the MC successfully objected the wedding the epilogue was a little happier. You know, maybe she goes to take a nap but kisses you first or something, just to show they're going to be on the right track.I was ridiculously attatched to everybody I met in this game.I started playing at about 10 pm last night, it's just about to turn 5 am. Night well spent.

Posted: March 1, 2015
												A well crafted and enjoyable RPG, Always Sometimes Monsters is a nice getaway from what many might conceive to be a bland market. It has quirks and charms that you don't find in many games, and the gameplay is well paced and not overwhelmingly long, leaving the player content at the end. Music and sound are good, dialogue tends to be pretty decent, and the storyline is almost believable - again, something reasonably rare for a game.Only real fault I can find is that it may take a few hours of gameplay to pull you in, but I'd say it's worth it for the finished product. 7/10 for sure

Posted: August 14, 2015
												1. Stole Sam's college crush2. Cuts Sam out of the deal and a year passed3. Things didnt work out with Sam's crush a.k.a MY girlfriend4. Got broke and can't pay for apartment rent5. Received wedding invitation from ex-girlfriend6. Got upset irl and wants to know wtf is going on7. Determined to attend ex-girlfriend's wedding8. Tried to find a job at kindergarten for travelling money9. Stole an anti-allergen shot and an inhaler there for lolz10. Gave a blow to a punk for a place to sleep11. Got a father of 4 children killed so I could get to wedding fasta12. Got to ex-girlfriend's house13.  Sam was the one she's planning to marry 14. Got very upset15.  Went along with Sam to her bachelorette party 16.  Got sam killed and got back with ex-girlfriend 17. Satisfied af18. Turns out the relationship still didnt last19. Upset irl again20. Got myself killed under the same bridge before. 20/10 This is better love story than Twilight.Honest review though ?If you're looking for an action RPG you've come to the wrong place. But if you're looking for an RPG where you tell your own story and live it the way you choose it to be, then this game can never go wrong. The choices you make actually impact your game further down the road. Maybe its just me, but this is the first time I've played an RPG game that's not so action packed but more towards story. I was expecting this to be boring but I was wrong. So hooked I was, that I played continuously for 12 hours straight in order to finish this game. Depending on how your choices are, you could be living like a homeless vagabond who's had it so hard in life and things keep turning out for the worse ( That was my playthrough ). Plus, there's quite a sum of minigames in the game as you uncover more of its story. My tip on enjoying this game is to immerse yourself in the story as you play and it will be worth it. Although this game turned out to be a spectacular gem, there is something missing that I cannot quite put my finger on. Perhaps the lack of story since it all leads one-way instead of able to branch out and expand to something new (Despite the many choices you are able to make). Or perhaps that the game is very short and replayability is not quite there. Nevertheless, if this game had a sequel I would surely have no second thoughts on getting it. Kudos to the devs.8.5/10P/S : Devs, please make a sequel

Posted: July 8, 2015
												I don't write a whole lot of reviews, but I felt this game absolutely deserved one more Steam recommendation.Always Sometimes Monsters is a fine example of an indie game made with heart but moreover an exempliary case of a story rich, content driven game. (Not that the graphics were bad for the retro sort of style. And the music was really good too!) Despite the risk of sounding tacky I'd describe ASM as a deep dive into the wide spectrum of humanity and life. It was funny, sad, clever, delightfully philosophic, beautiful, simple in a complex way - and genuinely thought-provoking at times.Regardless of the medium, I do enjoy stories and anecdotes that make the gamer/viewer/user reflect some element of their own life, perhaps questioning it or, on the other hand, feeling reassurance over it. Or maybe just cause that, either warm or melancholic, "Yeah, I can relate" feeling.The freedom of choice contributed to a great atmosphere throughout and I found myself quickly immersed each time I played. Also, unlike in other multiple-choice-type games I decided not to reload and replay each fork on the road and opted to just flow with it instead. It felt right not to see what might've been and instead just experience it uniquely as it happened - kinda like going through life itself.As someone who dabbles with writing stories as their dear hobby, I must say: hats off to the developers for their vision and unique approach! Video game experiences like this are few and far between! I consider Always Sometimes Monsters a good story, good game, and definately an experience worth recommending!

Posted: November 26, 2016
												Always Sometimes Monsters is an interesting game, not great by any means, but interesting enough to play.The basic idea is that you're a struggling person trying to win back someone you love, you deal with a lot of hardships along the way and have to make choices that define your personal character and how others see you! A great idea.. But I think this game had a few problems with executing it. Your choices do change some things around you and change some of the places you see during the game but that's about as far as it goes.. It's pretty easy to get around the mistakes you make throughout and that puts a damper on the struggles you're meant to go through. The game obviously had a lot of care put into it and it's definitely an interesting story to play through, the choices can keep you intrigued and the general game feel has a nice real-life gritty feel to it that I find appealing! But the game devs did a few things that really took me out of the game and made some of more irritating than enjoyable.. The self referencing the game devs have were far too often to really overlook it and the story didn't really come together in a nice enough way, it sort of felt.. Wrong.. Like they were trying very hard to make something deep but it didn't come together and just felt too forced in the end. The story concept wasn't the best and it showed through in an annoying way when the effect of your choices and everything were pushed on you. It just didn't come together well and trying to be philisophical just seemed tacky in this.Pros -The character selection is unique and character art is pleasing.You get to choose your love.The story is interesting enough to get you into it.Choices are intriguing!The pixel graphics were nice and the world was well designed.Had a sweet old lady.I got to sleep on a matress in an alley way and fish for my supper.Also gambled my money away with lotto tickets.Cons -Self referencing delevopers.No options!!The music got repetitive.The weight of your choices and the story seemed too forced and became irritating.I ran out of things to fish up.Overall it's okay, play it for yourself! but personally by the end of the game I was really torn as to whether I enjoyed it or not.

												While there are portions of this game I enjoyed as a whole it was a pretty unsatisfying experience. Like more than half the game is farming for money to pay some stupid bill or another, which I understand was meant to add a level of realism to the game because life can be tough as far as getting money for bills, but it just really took away from the story line because it took so long to progress anywhere. And then you get berated later in the game for doing some "shady" things for the money to progress the story? Like I wasn't really given another option, ♥♥♥♥ing sorry you don't like the way I had to earn money.The story itself wasn't my cup of tea from the start and it honestly just kept getting worse and more cliche. Like the whole point of this game is to reconnect with an ex who left years ago because you accidently find out she's getting married. Like, who the hell crashes a wedding for someone they haven't even talked to in years? So I didn't even want to continue with the story in the first place but I kept it up to see if it got any better or made some really good point at the end. No, it doesn't. You just end up sad and lonely and you look like a giant ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ and you learn nothing and you also just wasted all the ♥♥♥♥ing money you spent so many hours grinding to earn.Overall, it was just a lot of grinding away for a story that had little to no sustinence.

Posted: January 26
												This game may not be for everyone, but I loved the journey I went on. Unlike many other choice-based games (I'm looking at you Telltale, even though I love your games), the choices you make can greatly affect the outcome. Yes there are parts where it perhaps drags on a bit, but it only adds to the realism. The writing and characters are great, and I loved the message of the game. I tried to balance out acting morally and compromising my morals for the sake of making money in order to visit my true love.  Also, I loved the innovative way you pick who the protagonist and love interest are. I, for one, can't wait for the sequel.

Posted: March 5
												It's shenmue with drugs and broken relationships, for better or worse. I always sometimes appreciate everything this game tries to do, even if it sometimes gets tedious or frustrating or... outright bad in a few minute cases. The plot is compellingly written and the characters and situations you find yourself in are quite interesting. Really, ASM gets a pass almost exclusively due to how well-written it is. It's very good in that respect. It's when it remembers it's a game that it falters. Crawling around a labyrinthine series of ventilation shafts until I want TO DIE isn't really my idea of engaging the player with a deep narrative, and hauling around a ton of boxes - while strangely meditative in a way not entirely disimilar to shenmue's errant forklift simulation - just makes me think about everything else I could be doing with my time. I get why some of the more tedious moments are there, I just don't think certain parts of it work on the possibly-intended deeper conceptual level. Tedious is tedious. But most everything else is fine so I guess I can excuse a few moments of ABJECT SUFFERING. LET ME SUFFOCATE IN THE VENTS. THERE'S NOTHING ELSE FOR ME HERE.Always Sometimes Monsters is more than the sum of its parts. That's the tried-and-true way of saying that some parts of it are Not Good, but the thing's still worth playing.

Posted: April 17
												Always Sometimes Monsters was a game I picked up about 3 years ago during a July sale and I regret everything. This game could've been amazing but fell very flat for me. So let's get into the review.Pros:-Soundtrack is decent-Very nice art-Lovable, funny characters-Good sense of humor-Morality based chocies-You can name your character 'Titts McGee' or something equally as inmature and none of the characters seem to careCons:-'Moral' choices are not actually choices-ONE ending. ONE FREAKING ENDING-Lazy story telling towards the end-Characters do things out of character and ultimatley ruin everything-Goes for the predictable ending when it could've been something so much better-'Twist' MY♥♥♥♥♥SPOILERS REVIEW:The friend character Sam (girl or boy depending on which gender character you pick) ruins the whole game. They were a lovable character until the last hour. It's completely out of character for them to be a gambler and then OF COURSE they have to be the guy whose telling the whole story. And then they get shot by the gansters? It literally makes no sense and makes me want to break a kitten's neck. Sam and your character STILL COULD'VE BEEN FRIENDS BUT NOPE. SHTTY STORYTELING.Overall: 5/10 for the art and side characters for stealing the show.
